title: State v. Funderburk
description: In this criminal case, following a conviction for trafficking in cocaine, Funderburk appeals the admission of certain evidence.
text:
State v. Funderburk


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Retrice Lamont Funderburk, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4066
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; Â and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Retrice Lamont Funderburk appeals following a conviction for trafficking in cocaine.Â  Specifically, Funderburk argues the trial court improperly admitted evidence.Â  We affirm.Â Â Â  
FACTS
On November 16, 2000, Officers David Robinson and John McIntyre were patrolling Interstate I-85 in Greenville County when they observed a vehicle traveling too closely to an eighteen-wheeler truck.Â  After activating his blue lights and stopping the vehicle, Robinson approached the passenger side of the car.Â  Arriving at the passenger window, he noticed a female in the driverâ€™s seat, a male in the passengerâ€™s seat, and smelled what he believed to be burnt marijuana.Â  
After a brief conversation with the occupants, Robinson asked the driver, Debbie Lipscomb, to step out of the car so he could issue her a warning for following too close.Â  While Robinson was writing the warning, he asked Lipscomb about her travels and learned the car belonged to the passengerâ€™s mother.Â  As he was talking to Lipscomb, Robinson saw the passenger, Retrice Funderburk, make several hand gestures out of the window.Â  Robinson walked back to the vehicle and asked Funderburk if he needed anything.Â  Approaching the car, Robinson again smelled the odor of burnt marijuana.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Robinson briefly talked with Funderburk and then asked for consent to search the vehicle.Â  Funderburk initially agreed to â€œopen up thingsâ€ for Robinson, but was told, for safety reasons, â€œhe couldnâ€™t do that.â€Â  Robinson then asked Funderburk to exit the car and leave the keys on the seat.Â  After Funderburk exited the vehicle, Robinson again asked for consent to search.Â  Funderburk responded by pointing toward the vehicle and saying â€œgo ahead.â€Â  Robinson conducted a brief visual search of the interior and then proceeded to the rear of the vehicle.Â  Robinson opened the trunk and searched through its contents. Â Soon thereafter, Funderburk questioned why the search was necessary.Â  Robinson then asked, once again, if he could search and Funderburk responded, â€œyes, you can.â€Â  After searching a few bags, Robinson put his hand on a black bag and felt two hard brick-shaped items that, from experience, he identified as either cocaine or marijuana.Â  Funderburk claimed ownership of the bag and then asked Robinson to stop the search.Â  Robinson stopped the search and instructed McIntyre to arrest Funderburk.Â  A struggle ensued, but Funderburk was eventually apprehended.Â  A more thorough search of the bag yielded 3.27 pounds of cocaine.Â  After Funderburk was restrained, Robinson found two blunts, or cigars filled with marijuana, in the vehicle.Â Â  
A Greenville County grand jury indicted Funderburk for trafficking in cocaine and resisting arrest.Â  At trial, Funderburk moved to suppress the cocaine, arguing the search exceeded the scope of consent and the officers lacked probable cause to search the trunk.Â  Over his objection, the court allowed evidence and testimony regarding the cocaine.Â Â Â  
In addition, Funderburk objected to testimony which referred to the â€œbluntsâ€ as marijuana.Â  Funderburk argued that the substance was not tested, but the trial court allowed the testimony, ruling that Robinson may â€œtestify as to what his state of mind was.â€Â  Funderburk also objected to the introduction of the blunts into evidence, again arguing the State never definitively determined the substance to be marijuana and that introduction of the evidence was prejudicial.Â  Again, the court allowed the evidence over objection.Â Â Â Â  
At the close of trial, the jury found Funderburk guilty of trafficking in cocaine.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  The appellate court â€œis bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.â€Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 452, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000).Â  The appellate court â€œdoes not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.
â€œThe admission of evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002) (citations omitted).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.â€Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000) (quoting Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.                 
Scope of Consent 
Funderburk argues the trial court erred in denying counselâ€™s motion to suppress the cocaine found in the trunk because the officerâ€™s search exceeded the scope of consent.Â  We disagree. 
â€œUnder our state constitution, suspects are free to limit the scope of the searches to which they consent.â€Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 648, 541 S.E.2d 837, 843 (2001).Â  â€œWhen relying on the consent of a suspect, a police officerâ€™s search must not exceed the scope of the consent granted or the search becomes unreasonable.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe scope of the consent is measured by a test of â€˜objectiveâ€™ reasonableness--what would the typical reasonable person have understood by the exchange between the officer and the suspect?â€Â  State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 585-86, 575 S.E.2d 852, 856 (Ct. App. 2003) (citation omitted).Â  
We hold the trial court did not err in denying the motion to suppress because evidence exists to support the finding that Funderburkâ€™s consent included a search of the trunk.Â  First, the record indicates Funderburk imposed no limits on the scope of his consent to a search. Funderburk consented to the search of the vehicle three times: (1) before he exited the vehicle he agreed to â€œopen things upâ€; (2) as he walked away from the vehicle he pointed at the car and stated â€œgo aheadâ€; and (3) when Robinson asked about searching the trunk, Funderburk told him â€œyes, you can.â€ 
Second, Funderburk failed to object to Robinsonâ€™s search.Â  â€œ[A] suspectâ€™s failure to object (or withdraw his consent) when an officer exceeds limits allegedly set by the suspect is a strong indicator that the search was within the proper bounds of the consent search.â€Â  United States v. Jones, 356 F.3d 529, 534 (4th Cir. 2004) (citations omitted).Â  Here, Funderburk failed to withdraw his consent when Robinson searched through the vehicleâ€™s trunk. Therefore, the record demonstrates the scope of consent was not exceeded. Because Funderburk gave a general consent to a search of the vehicle and failed to object to Robinsonâ€™s search, we find the trial courtâ€™s ruling was supported by the evidence, and, therefore, we find no error.Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
II.              
Evidence/Testimony Regarding Marijuana 
Funderburk argues on appeal, that the trial court erred in allowing the testimony and evidence regarding marijuana found during the search because it constituted improper propensity evidence pursuant to State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  We disagree. 
At trial, Funderburk objected to the admission of the marijuana evidence based on an improper foundation.Â  Specifically, he argued the substance was never tested and/or analyzed and because of this, the substanceâ€™s admission, or testimony regarding it, would be improper.Â  At no time did Funderburk raise an objection based on Lyle.Â  Because Funderburkâ€™s arguments concerning propensity evidence were not presented to the trial court, we find they are not preserved for our review.Â Â  See, e.g., Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 102, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€). 
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
 AFFIRMED. [1]
STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

description: Laurine Coponen ran through a stop sign at an intersection and collided with David Underwoodâ€™s car.  Underwood brought an action against Carolyn Webb, the personal representative of Ansel Taylorâ€™s estate, alleging Taylor was negligent in failing to trim a tree located on his property, thereby contributing to the accident.  The trial court granted Webbâ€™s motion for summary judgment, which Underwood now appeals.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David R. Underwood, Appellant,
v.
Laurine H. Coponen, Carolyn T. Webb, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Ansel B. Taylor, and County of Greenville,
Defendants,
Of Whom Carolyn T. Webb, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Ansel B. Taylor is the
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4067
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William H. Ehlies, II, of Greenville, for Appellant.
John P. Riordan and Zandra L. Johnson, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â  Laurine Coponen ran through a stop sign at an intersection and collided with David Underwoodâ€™s car.Â  Underwood brought an action against Carolyn Webb, the personal representative of Ansel Taylorâ€™s estate, alleging Taylor was negligent in failing to trim a tree located on his property, thereby contributing to the accident.Â  The trial court granted Webbâ€™s motion for summary judgment, which Underwood now appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
    On May 4, 2002, Underwood was driving on Ansel School Road in Greenville County when Coponen ran through a stop sign at the intersection of Ansel School Road and Sharon Drive and collided with Underwoodâ€™s car.Â  Coponen testified that she did not see the stop sign because the limbs of a tree located on Taylorâ€™s property were partially blocking the sign.Â  The respondent, Webb, is the personal representative of Taylorâ€™s estate.Â  Taylorâ€™s wife testified that Taylor was aware the treeâ€™s limbs could obscure the stop sign and occasionally trimmed the tree to prevent it from doing so.Â  Coponen testified that she had driven on Sharon Drive before; however, she also testified that she was not looking for a stop sign because she mistakenly thought she was on another road that did not have stop signs.Â  
    Underwood initially brought this action solely against Coponen, alleging that she was liable for his injuries from the collision because she was negligent in running the stop sign.Â  However, on October 23, 2003, Underwood amended his complaint to include both Webb and Greenville County as additional defendants, alleging that either or both were negligent in failing to trim the tree located on Taylorâ€™s property, thereby contributing to the accident.Â  Webb filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  After a hearing on November 2, 2004, the trial judge granted Webbâ€™s motion.Â  A settlement was reached between Underwood and the other defendants.Â  Underwood now appeals.Â  
    STANDARD OF REVIEW 
        When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, we apply the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â 
        â€œWhen determining if any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Id. at 494-495, 567 S.E.2d at 860.Â  â€œIf triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.â€Â 
        Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 5, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct. App. 2004).
        LAW/ANALYSIS
              Underwood argues the trial court erred by granting Webbâ€™s motion for summary judgment because Taylor owed a duty of care to Underwood as a matter of law.Â  We disagree.
                â€œTo prevail on a theory of negligence, the plaintiff must establish three elements: (1) that defendant owed a plaintiff a duty of care; (2) that by some act or omission, defendant breached that duty; and (3) that as a proximate result of the breach, the plaintiff suffered damage.â€Â  Staples v. Duell, 329 S.C. 503, 506, 494 S.E.2d 639, 641 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œThe court must determine, as a matter of law, whether the law recognizes a particular duty.Â  If there is no duty, then the defendant in a negligence action is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â 
                Simmons v. Tuomey Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 341 S.C. 32, 39, 533 S.E.2d 312, 316 (2000).
                In South Carolina, urban landowners have a duty of reasonable care to inspect trees on their property and to make certain they are safe.Â  Staples, 329 S.C. at 508, 494 S.E.2d at 641-42 (quoting W. Page Keeton et al., Prosser and Keeton on the Law of Torts, Â§ 57 at 391 (5th ed. 1984)); Israel v. Carolina Bar-B-Que, Inc., 292 S.C. 282, 288, 356 S.E.2d 123, 127 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Also, landowners have a duty of reasonable care to make certain their trees are safe for travelers of streets adjoining their land.Â  Staples, 329 S.C. at 508, 494 S.E.2d at 642.Â  In Israel v. Carolina Bar-B-Que, 292 S.C. 282, 288-90, 356 S.E.2d 123, 127-28 (Ct. App. 1987), we held that a landowner has a duty to protect others from â€œdefective or unsound trees on his premisesâ€ and found the landowner was liable for the damage caused by the fallen tree limb because there was evidence that the owner either saw or could have seen upon reasonable inspection that the tree that caused the damage was partially decayed. 
                In this case, Taylorâ€™s tree was not unsafe or defective.Â  The tree limb did not fall and injure Coponen.Â  The only effect the tree limb had was that it partially obscured the stop sign, which Coponen testified that she was not looking for because she thought that she was driving on another street, which does not have stop signs.Â  Therefore, the rule set forth in Israel does not apply to the facts in this case.[2]Â  
                Underwood also claims that because Taylor periodically trimmed the tree on his property, he undertook the duty to keep his tree from blocking the stop sign.Â  However, the Restatement (Second) of Torts provides:

                One who undertakes, gratuitously or for consideration, to render services to another which he should recognize as necessary for the protection of the otherâ€™s person or things, is subject to liability to the other for physical harm resulting from his failure to exercise reasonable care to perform his undertaking, if (a) his failure to exercise such care increases the risk of such harm, or (b) the harm is suffered because of the otherâ€™s reliance upon the undertaking.Â  

                Staples, 329 S.C. at 510, 494 S.E.2d at 643 (quoting Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 323(a) (1965)). Â While Taylor did trim the tree occasionally for the purpose of clearing the stop sign and his failure to trim the tree might have increased the risk that the sign would be obstructed, neither Underwood nor Coponen knew that Taylor trimmed the tree, and thus they did not rely on his doing so.Â  Therefore, Taylorâ€™s occasional trimming of his tree did not create a duty for which he can be held liable.[3]Â  Additionally, even if Taylor had assumed a duty to trim the trees, he could have abandoned the duty at any time so long as his actions did not increase any risk that might have existed.Â  See Id. at 506, 494 S.E.2d at 641 (affirming the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the defendantâ€™s policy of searching for dead trees did not create a duty because he could have abandoned the policy at any time as long as doing so would not increase the risk of harm). 
                AFFIRMED.
                GOOLSBY, and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.
            
            [1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
            [2] In making their decision, the Israel court adopted Illinoisâ€™ ruling in Mahurin v. Lockhart, 390 N.E.2d 523 (Ill. 1979).Â  Therefore, it is worth noting that subsequent to publishing the Mahurin decision, Illinois issued several opinions on visual obstructions.Â  In Nichols v. Sitko, 510 N.E.2d 971, 974 (App. Ct. Ill. 1987), the court refused to extend the Mahurin rule, which involved an injury caused by a fallen dead branch, to an alleged visual obstruction from overgrown weeds.Â  The court reasoned that the alleged obstruction was â€œno different from obstructions which are caused by houses and buildings encountered routinely in daily life.â€Â  Id.Â  Also, in Adame v. Munoz, 678 N.E.2d 26, 29 (App. Ct. Ill. 1997), the court held that there is no duty â€œon the part of landowners to maintain their property in such a way that it does not obstruct the view of travelers on an adjacent highway, and this refusal to find such a duty applies even where the obstruction is an artificial condition.â€
            [3]  We further note that not imposing a duty on Taylor promotes good public policy.Â  If we extended the duty to require private landowners to ensure that their trees do not hinder traffic control devises, we would be discouraging private landowners from voluntarily maintaining vegetation on their property which adjoins a public roadway or highway in an effort to shield themselves from unwarranted liability.Â Â

title: McDill v. Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc.
description: Gerri B. McDill appeals from a jury verdict in favor of the defendants in this auto accident case, arguing the trial court abused its discretion in failing to qualify a trooper as an expert in accident reconstruction and to allow his opinion testimony regarding the cause of the accident.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Gerri B. McDill, individually and as Guardian ad Litem for Garrett B.
McDill, Appellant,
v.
Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc., J. Mark Lawhon, DMD, James Marion
Lawhon, Jr., and Christopher M. Lawhon, a minor over the age of fourteen, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4068
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed January 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William P. Hatfield and Robert D. McKissick, both of Florence, for Appellant.
Charles E. Carpenter, Carmen V. Ganjehsani, G.D. Morgan, Jr., Albert R. Pierce, Jr., Karl S. Brehmer, and J. Austin Hood, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Gerri B. McDill filed this action on behalf of herself and her minor son, Garrett,[1] alleging Garrett suffered severe injuries in an automobile collision caused by Christopher Lawhon, a minor over the age of fourteen.Â  In her lawsuit McDill asserted claims against Christopher as well as his father, Dr. Mark Lawhon; his grandfather, James M. Lawhon; and the grandfatherâ€™s business, Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc.Â  McDill appeals from a jury verdict in favor of the defendants, arguing the trial court abused its discretion in failing to qualify a trooper as an expert in accident reconstruction and to allow his opinion testimony regarding the cause of the accident.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Shortly after 6:00 p.m. on July 23, 2001, Garrett McDill, then 15, was seriously injured while driving a 1992 Honda Accord that collided with a 1997 Camaro driven by Christopher Lawhon, also 15.Â  The accident occurred as the two cars traveled in the same direction in adjacent lanes of West Palmetto Street, a four-lane road in Florence.Â  
Just before the accident, Christopher had recognized Garrett and madeÂ  a U-turn and then accelerated to catch up with him.Â  Garrett likewise recognized Christopher and several passengers in his car.Â  As they traveled next to each other on the four-lane road, Garrett was on the left and Christopher was on the right.Â  It had been raining most of the day and water had collected in the right-hand lane.Â  According to Garrett and one of his passengers, Christopher hit a puddle and then struck Garrettâ€™s car, causing it to slide sideways and then wrap around a utility pole.Â  In contrast, Christopher denied causing the accident, asserting Garrett was the one who apparently hit a puddle and then struck his vehicle.Â  
Gerri McDill brought this action on behalf of herself and Garrett against Christopher, his father, his grandfather, and his grandfatherâ€™s car dealership, Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc., which held title to the Camaro Christopher was driving at the time of the accident.Â  A jury returned a verdict in favor of the defendants.[2]Â  The trial court thereafter denied McDillâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, McDill argues the trial court committed reversible error in failing to qualify Trooper Bernard Williams of the South Carolina Highway Patrol as an expert in accident reconstruction and in excluding his opinion testimony that Christopher caused the automobile accident.Â  We disagree.
At the start of the trial, McDill asked that Trooper Williamsâ€™s opinion regarding the cause of the accident be admitted as expert testimony.Â  The testimony was from Trooper Williamsâ€™s deposition â€“ he was not present at trial.Â  The defendants objected, arguing Trooper Williams was never listed as an expert witness in the area of accident reconstruction and he had never been qualified as such; therefore, although factual testimony as to his investigation was allowable, any testimony specifically regarding his opinion as to causation should be excluded.Â Â Â  
In his deposition, Trooper Williams testified that he was called to the scene of the accident and while there he spoke to Christopher, whom he identified as the driver of one of the vehicles in the accident.Â  Trooper Williams stated Christopher told him that he had hit a puddle of water on the roadway and that it caused him to hydroplane and slide into the left lane where Garrett was traveling.Â  Trooper Williams additionally stated that after his visit to the scene, based on his experience, it was his opinion that Christopher most probably caused the accident by striking a puddle and then hydroplaning into the left lane where Garrett was traveling.Â  
After reviewing the deposition testimony, the trial court sustained the defendantsâ€™ objection, ruling McDill had not established a sufficient basis to qualify Trooper Williams as an expert and to permit him to give an opinion.Â  The court stated, however, that Trooper Williamsâ€™s testimony regarding adverse statements allegedly made to him by Christopher at the scene, i.e., that he was traveling in the right lane, hit water, and then hydroplaned, striking the rear of Garrettâ€™s vehicle, would be admissible as fact evidence for which it was not necessary that Trooper Williams be qualified as an expert or give expert opinion testimony.Â  During the trial, portions of Trooper Williamsâ€™s recorded deposition were subsequently played for the jury.Â  Christopher denied at trial ever having made the alleged statements to Trooper Williams.Â  
After the jury returned a verdict for the defendants, McDill filed a motion for a new trial alleging, among other things, that the trial court erred in excluding the opinion testimony of Trooper Williams as to the cause of the automobile accident.Â  The trial court denied McDillâ€™s motion, finding it had properly excluded any opinion testimony from Trooper Williams because â€œneither Trooper Williamsâ€™[s] training nor testimony supported a ruling that he qualified as an expert in accident reconstructionâ€ and â€œ[b]y Trooper Williamsâ€™[s] own admission, he was not qualified to testify regarding accident reconstruction.â€Â  
â€œTo qualify as an expert, a person must have acquired by study or practical experience a special knowledge of a subject matter about which the juryâ€™s good judgment and average knowledge is inadequate.â€Â  Manning v. City of Columbia, 297 S.C. 451, 453-54, 377 S.E.2d 335, 337 (1989).
The qualification of an expert witness and the admissibility of his or her opinion are matters resting within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Id. at 453, 377 S.E.2d at 336-37.Â  On appeal, we will not disturb the trial judgeâ€™s ruling absent an abuse of that discretion and a showing of prejudice.Â  Strange v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 307 S.C. 161, 163, 414 S.E.2d 138, 139 (1992).
â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).Â  â€œA trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of an expertâ€™s testimony constitutes an abuse of discretion when the ruling is manifestly arbitrary, unreasonable, or unfair.â€Â  Id.
To the extent McDill contends the trial court abused its discretion in failing to qualify Trooper Williams as an expert in accident reconstruction, we find no error in this regard.Â  Aside from the fact that Trooper Williams was, admittedly, never listed as an expert witness by McDill,[3] there is evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s concerns as to his qualifications as an expert in accident reconstruction.Â  It was undisputed that Trooper Williams had experience in investigating accidents as a highway patrolman and that he did take a six-week accident reconstruction course in 1995 or 1996, as well as a few updating courses, but he was not a member of the Highway Patrolâ€™s official accident reconstruction team.Â  We note that when Trooper Williams was asked how he determined the approximate speeds of the two drivers in this accident, he stated he based it on what the drivers told him, as he did not have any evidence to the contrary.Â  Thus, he did not use any particular reconstructive techniques in making this determination.Â  He also apparently was allowed to give his opinion in a federal court proceeding, but that was because none of the attorneys objected to his testimony.Â  Thus, the court was not specifically asked to make a determination regarding his qualifications.[4]Â Â Â  
Just as a trial court has broad discretion in qualifying a witness as an expert, which this court may not overturn on appeal, a trial court also has broad discretion in deciding not to qualify a witness as an expert.Â  As noted by Lawhon in his brief, if investigating an accident qualified an officer as an expert in accident causation, then every highway patrolman would qualify as an expert.Â  At most, the testimony presented by McDill established that Trooper Williams had investigated automobile accidents and possibly gave an opinion in a federal court proceeding regarding accident investigation.Â  Upon reviewing the record, we hold McDill has not clearly demonstrated the trial court abused its discretion in failing to qualify Trooper Williams as an expert in accident reconstruction.
In any event, even assuming it was error to fail to qualify Trooper Williams as an expert, McDill has not established prejudice warranting reversal.Â  See Owners Ins. Co. v. Clayton, 364 S.C. 555, 563, 614 S.E.2d 611, 615 (2005) (â€œError without prejudice does not warrant reversal.â€); Fields, 363 S.C. at 26, 609 S.E.2d at 509 (â€œTo warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., that there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the challenged evidence or the lack thereof.â€). 
As noted above, Trooper Williams was listed as a fact witness and the trial court allowed portions of his deposition testimony, with his opinion redacted, to be presented to the jury.Â  The jury was given Trooper Williamsâ€™s testimony that Christopher allegedly told him at the scene of the accident that he had hit a puddle, hydroplaned, and then moved over into the left lane, striking Garrettâ€™s vehicle.Â  This information is basically the same as the trooperâ€™s opinion that Christopher had hit a puddle and then hydroplaned into Garrettâ€™s vehicle.Â  It was up to the jury, as the finder of fact, to judge the credibility of the witnesses and to resolve any conflicts in their testimony.Â  See, e.g., Curcio v. Caterpillar, Inc., 355 S.C. 316, 320, 585 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2003) (holding it is up to a jury to decide credibility issues and to resolve any conflicts in the testimony or the evidence); Getsinger v. Midlands Orthopaedic Profit Sharing Plan, 327 S.C. 424, 428, 489 S.E.2d 223, 225 (Ct. App. 1997) (stating conflicts in the testimony are for the jury to resolve as the finder of fact) (citing Garrett v. Locke, 309 S.C. 94, 419 S.E.2d 842 (Ct. App. 1992)).
 
    AFFIRMED.
SHORT, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  Garrettâ€™s name also appears spelled as â€œGarretâ€ in the Record on Appeal.
[2]Â  The jury answered â€œNoâ€ to the following question, at which point it ceased further deliberation as per the instructions on the verdict form:Â  â€œDo you find that the Defendant Christopher Lawhon was negligent and that such negligence proximately caused the Plaintiffsâ€™ injuries?â€Â  
[3]Â  See Strange, 307 S.C. at 164, 414 S.E.2d at 139 (holding the trial court abused its discretion in qualifying the plaintiffsâ€™ expert as an expert in accident reconstruction where the plaintiffs had not identified their expert witness as being an expert in this field in addition to the fields of traffic engineering and geometric design prior to trial).Â  
[4]Â  During his deposition, McDillâ€™s attorney asked Trooper Williams whether he had previously been qualified in court as an expert in the area of accident reconstruction.Â  One of the defense attorneys objected on the basis of relevance.Â  Trooper Williams was somewhat unsure in his answer, stating, â€œYes.Â  Iâ€™m not sure about the reconstruction part, but as far as the accident investigation, yes . . . .â€Â

title: State v. Patterson
description: Appellant was convicted of murder.  The issues on appeal are: (1) did the judge err by ruling a witnessâ€™s entire statement to the police could be read to the jury under Rule 106, SCRE; (2) did the judge err by refusing to instruct the jury on causation and/or proximate cause where there was evidence the victim was taken off of a respirator and her feeding tube removed; and (3) did the judge err by ruling Appellant could not waive his presence during a witnessâ€™s testimony.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Frank Robert Patterson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4069
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed January 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter III; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Frank Robert Patterson appeals his conviction for murder.Â  He argues the trial court erred (1) in admitting a witnessâ€™s statement to police; (2) by requiring Pattersonâ€™s presence during the videotaping of a witnessâ€™s testimony; and (3) by refusing to charge the jury on proximate cause.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Patterson was accused of murdering his girlfriend, Sharon Clark, by beating her to death.Â  Clark and her friend, Mary Richardson, walked to Pattersonâ€™s home where the three of them drank for several hours.Â  Later that night, Clark and Richardson decided to leave despite Pattersonâ€™s insistence Clark should stay.Â  As Richardson and Clark walked away, Patterson began striking Clark repeatedly with a blunt instrument.Â  
Richardson screamed at Patterson to stop hitting Clark.Â  She ran to a neighborâ€™s house for assistance.Â  When Richardson returned to the scene, she saw Clark lying on the ground motionless.Â  Richardson ran down the street and flagged down a police car in the neighborhood.Â  Richardson led the officer to Clarkâ€™s location.Â  Patterson, with his clothes bloody, returned to the scene while the officer was there.Â  He admitted he had beaten Clark and was arrested.
Clark was taken to Richland Memorial Hospital where she was placed on a respirator and immediately rushed into the first of her two surgeries.Â  Clarkâ€™s skull was cracked in multiple places, and she had skull fragments in her brain.Â  She lost a significant amount of blood due to the severity of her head injury.Â  Clarkâ€™s prognosis was poor; she was taken off life support nine days later.Â  Her feeding tube was removed on March 25, and she died on March 27.Â  
The grand jury indicted Patterson for murder.Â  Due to medical reasons, Richardsonâ€™s testimony was videotaped. Â At the hearing, Patterson requested that he be allowed to waive his presence.Â  The trial court refused his request.Â  At trial, the jury found Patterson guilty of murder, and the trial court sentenced Patterson to life without parole. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 613 S.E.2d 381 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThe appellate court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence, but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€Â  State v. Staten, 364 S.C. 7, 15, 610 S.E.2d 823, 827 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003)); see also State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 101, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œIn criminal cases, the court of appeals sits to review errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.â€).Â  This Court should examine the record to determine whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  See Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â Â  
On review, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 613 S.E.2d 381.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In order for an error to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant. See State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); see also State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 453 S.E.2d 890 (1995) (holding error without prejudice does not warrant reversal).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Rule 106, SCRE
Patterson claims the trial court erred in admitting Richardsonâ€™s entire statement to police on redirect examination.Â  We disagree.
The State and defense counsel agreed to take Richardsonâ€™s testimony by video before trial.Â  Richardson testified that while she was talking to police on the night of Clarkâ€™s murder, Patterson returned to the scene, walked up to Clark, pointed to her and said, â€œYou see that right there? I did that.â€Â  On cross-examination, defense counsel elicited from Richardson that she believed the accuracy of her account of the murder to police was very important.Â  Richardson indicated she carefully read her statement to police before she affixed her signature.Â  Defense counsel then handed Richardson her statement and asked if Pattersonâ€™s admission was included in the statement.Â  Richardson conceded her statement to police did not include Pattersonâ€™s admission.Â  On redirect examination, the State argued defense counsel had, by cross-examining Richardson on her statement, opened the door to admit Richardsonâ€™s entire statement to police.Â  Despite objections from defense counsel that Richardson had merely been asked about an omission in the report, the trial court allowed Richardson to publish the statement in its entirety.Â  
Significantly, Richardsonâ€™s testimony on redirect examination was not played for the jury.Â  At trial, the defense stated:

  
    
      
        Ms.
          Pringle:   
         Your Honor, Iâ€™ll go ahead and put on the record with respect to the next witness who is a Mary Richardson,
          we have stipulated with the Solicitorâ€™s Office previously that Ms. Richardsonâ€™s testimony may be admitted by videotape, previously taped testimony 2002.Â  Your Honor, we of course obviously have no problem with the admission of the videotape in lieu of her testimony even though it is our understanding that she may be available to testify; with one caveat, Your Honor, that
          we have agreed to cut the tape off at the end of cross-examination.Â 
          Mr. Cathcart indicates that he is going to just walk right up there and turn it off as soon as the end of cross.
      
      
        
        
      
      
        Mr. Cathcart:    
         I believe the area she is talking about is the redirect by the State.
      
    
  

(Emphasis added.)Â  The record indicates that the videotape was played for the jury.Â  No objection was made at the conclusion of the taped testimony.Â  
Initially, we note the issue of whether Richardsonâ€™s statement to police was properly admitted into evidence is not properly before this Court.Â  Pursuant to the partiesâ€™ stipulation, the jury never heard Richardson publish her statement.Â  Although counsel timely objected to publication of the statement at the time Richardsonâ€™s testimony was being taped, at trial, the videotape was played without objection by the defense. Objecting to admission of a statement during pretrial video testimony does not preserve an issue for review.Â  Cf. State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 250, 609 S.E.2d 572, 587 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 647, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001); State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 561 S.E.2d 640 (Ct. App. 2002)).Â  To preserve an issue for appellate review, a contemporaneous objection must be made when the evidence is offered. See State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 193 n. 3, 498 S.E.2d 642, 644 n. 3 (1998) (citing State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 42, 479 S.E.2d 57, 60 (1996) (â€œUnless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling made, the issue is not preserved for review.â€)); State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 41, 476 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996) (â€œ[A]ppellant made no contemporaneous objection at trial and did not raise this issue at any point during trial. Consequently, this issue is not preserved for review.â€); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993). 
Adverting to the merits, we find the trial court properly ruled Richardsonâ€™s statement to police was admissible.Â  Rule 106, SCRE provides:

When a writing, or recorded statement, or part thereof is introduced by a party, an adverse party may require the introduction at that time of any other part or any other writing or recorded statement which ought in fairness to be considered contemporaneously with it. 

Rule 106 was promulgated by Order of the Supreme Court and became effective September 3, 1995.Â  See Editorâ€™s Note, Rule 106, SCRE.Â  The Rule restates the common law rule of completeness with one significant change.Â  Prior to the enactment of Rule 106, when part of a document, writing, or conversation was introduced into evidence, the opposing party could introduce the remainder of the communication.Â  See Dukes v. Smoak, 181 S.C. 182, 186 S.E. 780 (1936).Â  However, whereas under common law the opposing party was required to wait until cross-examination to complete the communication, under Rule 106, the party can now require introduction of the remainder of the statement contemporaneous with the original proffer.Â  See Rule 106, SCRE.Â  
As the South Carolina Supreme Court explained in State v. Taylor, â€œThe text of Rule 106, SCRE, is substantially similar to Rule 106 of the Federal Rules of Evidence.Â  Rule 106, Fed.R.Evid., is based on the rule of completeness and seeks to avoid the unfairness inherent in the misleading impression created by taking matters out of context.â€Â  333 S.C. 159, 170, 508 S.E.2d 870, 876 (1998) (internal quotation marks omitted) (quoting Rainey v. Beech Aircraft Corp., 784 F.2d 1523, 1529 (11th Cir. 1986)).Â  The rule applies to oral communications as well as written statements.Â  State v. Cabrera-Pena, 361 S.C. 372, 379, 605 S.E.2d 522, 526 (2004); State v. Jackson, 265 S.C. 278, 284, 217 S.E.2d 794, 797 (1975).Â  
In Cabrera-Pena, the State elected to use a witness to elicit portions of the defendantâ€™s conversation.Â  361 S.C. at 380, 605 S.E.2d at 526.Â  Our supreme court found the rule of completeness required the defendant to be permitted to inquire into the full substance of the conversation.Â  Id.Â  Similarly, defense counsel, by asking Richardson whether her statement to police included Pattersonâ€™s admission, opened the door for the State to inquire into the full substance of her statement.Â  
Patterson argues that because the inquiry referred to an alleged omission by Richardson as opposed to an affirmative declaration in the statement, Rule 106 does not apply.Â Â  We disagree.
After eliciting testimony from Richardson regarding how careful she was in giving police a correct depiction of the events that led to Clarkâ€™s murder, defense counsel in essence insinuated Richardsonâ€™s statement to police was incomplete.Â  The defense put Richardsonâ€™s statement to police at issue, and fundamental fairness required the entire statement be admitted into evidence.Â  Patterson would have us construe Rule 106 in such a way that inquiries that probed at alleged omissions from a statement would not open the door to the admission of the statement. The purpose behind Rule 106 would be frustrated if the ruleâ€™s application in a given case depended upon whether an alleged oral assertion was or was not in a written statement. We find the rule of completeness applies to insinuations, innuendos, and omissions.Â  Thus, the trial judge properly admitted Richardsonâ€™s statement. 
Finally, even if the trial judge had erred in admitting the entire statement, Patterson has failed to demonstrate any resulting prejudice because the jury never heard the statement.Â  An error not shown to be prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversal. See State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 472-73, 613 S.E.2d 381, 384 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œA courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error, which results in prejudice to the defendant.â€) (citations omitted); Rule 103, SCRE (â€œError may not be predicated upon a ruling which admits or excludes evidence unless a substantial right of the party is affected[.]â€).Â  The jury never heard the disputed portion of the videotape, and therefore, we cannot discern any prejudice to Patterson.Â  State v. Gathers, 295 S.C. 476, 482, 369 S.E.2d 140, 143 (1988), affâ€™d, 490 U.S. 805 (1989).
II.Â  Presence During Videotaping of Witness Testimony
Patterson argues the trial court erred by requiring his presence during the videotaping of Richardsonâ€™s testimony.Â  Patterson maintains he was severely prejudiced by Richardsonâ€™s claim that he was smiling during the commission of the murder.Â  We disagree.
Patterson made no objection after Richardsonâ€™s video testimony was played for the jury, and, therefore, this issue is not preserved for review.Â  To preserve an issue for appellate review, a contemporaneous objection must be made when the evidence is offered. See State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 193 n. 3, 498 S.E.2d 642, 644 n. 3 (1998) (citing State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 42, 479 S.E.2d 57, 60 (1996) (â€œ[U]nless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling is procured, the issue is not preserved for review.â€)); State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 41, 476 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996) (â€œ[A]ppellant made no contemporaneous objection at trial and did not raise this issue at any point during trial. Consequently, this issue is not preserved for review.â€); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993). 
Even if the issue were properly preserved, we find the trial court did not err by requiring Pattersonâ€™s presence during the videotaping of Richardsonâ€™s testimony.Â  Pattersonâ€™s reliance on Rule 16, SCRCrimP is misplaced.
Rule 16, SCRCrimP provides:

Except in cases wherein capital punishment is a permissible sentence, a person indicted for misdemeanors and/or felonies may voluntarily waive his right to be present and may be tried in his absence upon a finding by the court that such person has received notice of his right to be present and that a warning was given that the trial would proceed in his absence upon a failure to attend court.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Apodictically, a criminal defendant has a constitutional right guaranteed by the Confrontation Clause of the Sixth Amendment to be present at trial.Â  See U.S. Const. amend. VI; Illinois v. Allen, 397 U.S. 337, 338 (1970) (â€œOne of the most basic of the rights guaranteed by the Confrontation Clause is the accusedâ€™s right to be present in the courtroom at every stage of his trial.â€).Â  While Rule 16 permits a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to be present, such a waiver is permitted only in limited circumstances.Â  â€œA trial judge must determine a defendant voluntarily waived his right to be present at trial in order to try the case in abstentia.â€Â  State v. Truesdale, 345 S.C. 542, 549, n. 5, 548 S.E.2d 896, 899, n. 5 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing State v. Rich, 292 S.C. 75, 76, 354 S.E.2d 909, 909 (1987); State v. Jackson, 288 S.C. 94, 95, 341 S.E.2d 375, 375 (1986); State v. Castineira, 341 S.C. 619, 622, 535 S.E.2d 449, 451 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  Additionally, the trial judge must make findings of fact that the defendant (1) received notice of the right to be present and (2) was warned the trial would proceed in his absence.Â  Jackson, 288 S.C. at 95, 341 S.E.2d at 375; Castineira, 341 S.C. at 622, 535 S.E.2d at 451.Â Â  
The right to be present at trial is not the right to be absent from trial.Â  A criminal defendant has no absolute right to be absent during trial proceedings.Â  In State v. Moore, the South Carolina Supreme Court held a defendant had no constitutional right to be absent from trial to prevent in-court identification.Â  308 S.C. 349, 351, 417 S.E.2d 869, 870 (1992).Â  The court found the State has a corresponding right to have the defendant present, elucidating: â€œâ€˜[I]t is the right of the prosecution to have [the defendant] in the view of the presiding judge and jury, and the counsel engaged in the trial.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting State v. Oâ€™Neal, 210 S.C. 305, 310-311, 42 S.E.2d 523, 525 (1947)).Â  In some circumstances, a defendant may be presumed to waive or forfeit the right to be present by misbehaving in the courtroom or by voluntarily remaining away from trial.Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 625, 545 S.E.2d 805, 815 (2001); State v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391, 401, 360 S.E.2d 706, 711 (1987); Ellis v. State, 267 S.C. 257, 260-61, 227 S.E.2d 304, 305-06 (1976).Â  However, even though a criminal defendant may waive or forfeit his right to participate in the proceedings, â€œa defendant has no contrasting right to be absent from trial, even when his absence might assist the defense.â€Â  5 Wayne R. LaFave, Jerold H. Isreal, Nancy J. King, Criminal Procedure Â§ 24.2(b) (1999) (citations omitted).
The conduct of a criminal trial is left largely to the sound discretion of the trial judge, who will not be reversed in the absence of a prejudicial abuse of discretion.Â  â€œThe general rule in this State is that the conduct of a criminal trial is left largely to the sound discretion of the presiding judge and this Court will not interfere unless it clearly appears that the rights of the complaining party were abused or prejudiced in some way.â€Â  State v. Bridges, 278 S.C. 447, 448, 298 S.E.2d 212, 212 (1982) (citing State v. Sinclair, 275 S.C. 608, 274 S.E.2d 411 (1981)); Cf. State v. Tuckness, 257 S.C. 295, 185 S.E.2d 607 (1971).Â  Pattersonâ€™s sole reason for desiring to be absent was his belief that he had a right to waive his presence.Â  Although a criminal defendant has a constitutional right to be present during court proceedings, the defendant has no absolute corresponding right to be absent.Â  The precedent extant edifies that a defendant may waive his right to be present in very limited scenarios.Â  The trial court did not err by refusing to allow Patterson to waive his presence at Richardsonâ€™s video hearing.Â  
Further, the alleged prejudicial statement was made during recross-examination and was not played for the jury.Â  Patterson could not have been prejudiced by testimony the jury never heard.Â  An error not shown to be prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversal.Â  See State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 472-73, 613 S.E.2d 381, 384 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œA courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error, which results in prejudice to the defendant.â€) (citations omitted); Rule 103, SCRE (â€œError may not be predicated upon a ruling which admits or excludes evidence unless a substantial right of the party is affected[.]â€).Â  Therefore, we find Patterson cannot show he was prejudiced.Â  See Gathers at 482, 369 S.E.2d at 143 (finding the duty is upon the defendant to prove prejudice.).Â  
III.Â  Jury Charge
Patterson contends the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on proximate cause because there was evidence Clarkâ€™s death was due to her removal from life support.Â  We disagree.
The law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.Â  State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 302, 555 S.E.2d 391, 394 (2001); State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 101, 525 S.E.2d 511, 512 (2000); State v. Lee, 298 S.C. 362, 364, 380 S.E.2d 834, 835 (1989); State v. Staten, 364 S.C. 7, 40, 610 S.E.2d 823, 840 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 450, 529 S.E.2d 721, 727 (2000) (citing Cohens v. Atkins, 333 S.C. 345, 349, 509 S.E.2d 286, 289 (Ct. App. 1998)); see also State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 106, 610 S.E.2d 859, 865 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œGenerally, the trial judge is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.â€) (citing Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 594 S.E.2d 462 (2004); State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 565 S.E.2d 298 (2002); State v. Buckner, 341 S.C. 241, 534 S.E.2d 15 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  â€œIn reviewing jury charges for error, we must consider the courtâ€™s jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.â€Â  Zeigler, 364 S.C. at 106, 610 S.E.2d at 865; accord State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 318, 577 S.E.2d 460, 463 (Ct. App. 2003).Â Â  A jury charge is correct if, when the charge is read as a whole, it contains the correct definition and adequately covers the law.Â  Adkins at 318, 577 S.E.2d at 463-64.Â  
To warrant reversal, a trial courtâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.Â  State v. Reese, 359 S.C. 260, 273, 597 S.E.2d 169, 176 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œFailure to give requested jury instructions is not prejudicial error where the instructions given afford the proper test for determining issues.â€ Burkhart, 350 S.C. at 263, 565 S.E.2d at 304.Â  â€œIf, as a whole, the charges are reasonably free from error, isolated portions which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  Zeigler, 364 S.C. at 106, 610 S.E.2d at 865 (citing State v. Sims, 304 S.C. 409, 405 S.E.2d 377 (1991); State v. Jackson, 297 S.C. 523, 377 S.E.2d 570 (1989)).Â  A jury charge which is substantially correct and covers the law does not require reversal.Â  State v. Foust, 325 S.C. 12, 479 S.E.2d 50 (1996); State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 440 S.E.2d 869 (1994).
Patterson relies on State v. Matthews, 291 S.C. 339, 353 S.E.2d 444 (1986), and State v. Jenkins, 276 S.C. 209, 277 S.E.2d 147 (1981), for the proposition that, at the very minimum, he was entitled to a jury charge on proximate cause.Â  
The sixteen-year-old decedent in Matthews was shot in the head and pronounced dead after being transported to a hospital.Â  Her kidneys were harvested and donated for transplantation.Â  The appellant, Earl Matthews, argued the doctors prematurely declared the victim dead.Â  Matthews maintained the removal of her kidneys was a superseding cause of death which relieved him of liability for her murder.Â  291 S.C. at 346, 353 S.E.2d at 448.Â  The appellant conceded negligent medical treatment would not relieve him of liability; however, he argued declaring the victim brain dead and removing her kidneys did not constitute medical treatment.Â  Id. at 346, 353 S.E.2d at 448-49.Â  Matthews objected to the trial courtâ€™s jury charge on the applicable law of proximate cause regarding medical treatment because he believed harvesting organs for transplanting did not constitute medical care.Â  Our supreme court disagreed: â€œThe decision to declare a patient dead and to harvest organs for transplantation is clearly part of the care or duty that a doctor is responsible for providing.Â  We hold that the actions of the doctor did constitute medical care.â€Â  Matthews, 291 S.C. at 347, 353 S.E.2d at 449.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In Jenkins, the victim had a rare, fatal reaction to the dye used in performing an arteriogramâ€”a common procedure administered to determine the extent of injuries to the major blood vessels.Â  276 S.C. at 210-11, 277 S.E.2d at 148. Â Evidence at trial showed the victim would have â€œsurvived absent the reaction, but that she would not have survived without medical treatment.â€Â  Id.Â  On appeal, Jenkins argued the trial court erred by failing to charge the jury on assault and battery with intent to kill and assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  The court noted the appellant did not challenge the sufficiency of the evidence to sustain the murder conviction, and therefore the trial court committed â€œno prejudicial error in refusing to submit to the jury the two degrees of assault and battery.â€Â  Id.Â  
Unlike the present case, both Jenkins and Matthews involved a medical procedure between the appellantâ€™s crime and the victimâ€™s death.Â  In Mathews, the appellant claimed the removal of the victimâ€™s kidneys was a superseding cause of death.Â  In Jenkins, despite appellantâ€™s contention that the victimâ€™s reaction to the dye was the cause of death, the South Carolina Supreme Court found no prejudice in the trial courtâ€™s failure to charge the jury as requested.Â  The court found â€œone who inflicts an injury on another is deemed by law to be guilty of homicide where the injury contributes mediately or immediately to the cause of the death of the other.â€Â  Jenkins, 276 S.C. at 211, 277 S.E.2d at 148 (emphasis added).Â  In neither case did appellant argue, as Patterson here argues, that removal from life support was the intervening cause of death.Â  
Because Clark showed signs of improvement, Patterson avers the doctors prematurely removed Clarkâ€™s ventilator and feeding tube.Â  The evidence shows Clark was operated on within thirty minutes of her arrival at the hospital due to the severity of her injuries.Â  Dr. Raymond Bynoe testified when Clark was brought to the hospital, â€œshe [had] lost at least a third of her blood volumeâ€ and â€œhad no spontaneous respiratory effort.â€Â  Additionally, Clarkâ€™s skull had an â€œeggshell type of appearance . . . which meant that it was cracked in multiple places[.]â€Â  Dr. Clay Nichols, a forensic pathologist corroborated the severity of Clarkâ€™s injuries, stating she sustained â€œsuch massive brain death and swelling that the dead brain tissue was . . . actually oozing out of the open skull fracture.â€ Â Clarkâ€™s cause of death, in Dr. Nicholsâ€™s opinion, was â€œ[m]assive blunt head trauma due to beating with a pipe.â€Â  The fact that she lived for a period of time after the beating had no effect as to the cause of her death and was in fact a â€œcompliment to the medical treatment she received at Richland Memorial.â€Â  Further, Dr. Nichols opined Clark would have â€œdied within minutes of . . . the injuryâ€ without medical attention.Â  
â€œCourts have confronted whether a victimâ€™s removal from life support renders a homicide verdict against the weight of the evidence and have rejected the contention that there was insufficient evidence to support a conviction[.]â€Â  State v. Pelham, 824 A.2d 1082, 1091 (N.J. 2003) (citing State v. Fierro, 603 P.2d 74 (Ariz. 1979); Porter v. State, 823 S.W.2d 846 (Ark. 1992); People v. Saldana, 121 Cal. Rptr. 243 (Ct. App. 1975); State v. Guess, 692 A.2d 849 (Conn. App. 1997), affâ€™d, 715 A.2d 643 (1998); Johnson v. State, 404 S.E.2d 108 (Ga. 1991); People v. Caldwell, 692 N.E.2d 448 (Ill. App. 1998); Ewing v. State, 719 N.E.2d 1221 (Ind. 1999); Carrigg v. State, 696 N.E.2d 392 (Ind. Ct. App. 1998); Spencer v. State, 660 N.E.2d 359 (Ind. Ct.App. 1996); People  v. Bowles, 607 N.W.2d 715 (Mich. 2000); State v. Olson, 435 N.W.2d 530 (Minn. 1989); State v. Meints, 322 N.W.2d 809 (Neb. 1982); People v. Laraby, 665 N.Y.S.2d 180 (N.Y. App. Div. 1997), affâ€™d, 703 N.E.2d 756 (N.Y. 1998); State v. Johnson, 381 N.E.2d 637 (Ohio 1978); Eby v. State, 702 P.2d 1047 (Okla. Crim. App. 1985); Commonwealth v. Kostra, 502 A.2d 1287 (Pa. Super. 1985); State v. Ruane, 912 S.W.2d 766 (Tenn. Crim. App. 1995); Felder v. State, 848 S.W.2d 85 (Tex. Crim. App. 1992), cert. denied, 510 U.S. 829 (1993)).
The trial court refused Pattersonâ€™s jury charge on proximate causation, finding the mere fact Clark was withdrawn from life support was not the cause of death.Â  In State v. Pelham, the New Jersey Supreme Court noted â€œthe widely recognized principle that removal of life support, as a matter of law, may not constitute an independent intervening cause for purposes of lessening a criminal defendantâ€™s liability.â€Â  Pelham, 824 A.2d at 1092; see also State v. Velarde, 734 P.2d 449, 455-56 (Utah 1986) (â€œ[R]emoval of the respirator was not the cause of death . . . . the neurological surgeon who performed the surgery on [the victim] after the assault, testified that blunt-instrument injuries were the cause of death.â€); State v. Yates, 824 P.2d 519, 523 (Wis. Ct. App. 1992) (â€œWhen life support is removed, the cause of death is not the removal, but whatever agency generated the need for life support in the first instance.â€). Â Other courts have denied requests by defendants for jury instructions charging that a victimâ€™s removal from life support constitutes an independent intervening cause sufficient to relieve the defendant of criminal liability.Â  See, e.g., People v. Funes, 28 Cal.Rptr.2d 758 (Ct. App. 1994); In re J.N., 406 A.2d 1275 (D.C. 1979); State v. Yates, 824 P.2d 519 (Wis. Ct. App. 1992) rehâ€™g denied, 833 P.2d 1390 (1992).Â Â  
The trial court has a duty to instruct the jury only on an issue that is supported by the evidence.Â  Knoten, 347 S.C. at 302, 555 S.E.2d at 394.Â  We find the trial court did not err in failing to instruct the jury on proximate cause.Â  The Stateâ€™s evidence clearly established Clark died from severe traumatic blows to the head.Â  Under these facts, the removal of life support cannot be considered an independent intervening cause capable of breaking the chain of causation triggered by the defendantâ€™s wrongful actions. Â 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the conviction of the appellant for murder is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.
