title: Tomlinson v. Mixon
description: Appellant All American Homes of NC, LLC argues the trial court erred in not requiring the respondents, Elwood and Frances Tomlinson, to elect their remedy after the jury returned a verdict in their favor on claims for negligent misrepresentation and breach of contract.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Elwood Porter Tomlinson and Frances Goins Tomlinson,
Respondents,
v.
Kenneth B. Mixon, d/b/a Pavillion Custom Homes, and All American Homes of NC, LLC,
Defendants,
Of Whom All American Homes of NC, LLC is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4070
Heard November 7, 2005 â€“ Filed January 9, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Robert W. Buffington, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Eric S. Bland, of Columbia and Ronald L. Richter, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This case involves claims for negligent misrepresentation and breach of contract.Â  The appellant, All American Homes of NC, LLC, a manufacturer of modular houses, contends the trial court erred in not requiring the respondents, Elwood and Frances Tomlinson, to elect their remedy after the jury returned a verdict in their favor on each claim.Â  We reverse and remand. 
The Tomlinsons decided to build a home on Lake Wateree and contacted defendant Kenneth B. Mixon, doing business as Pavillion Custom Homes.Â  Mixon held himself out as an All American authorized dealer.Â  An All American business card also identified him as such. Â Â Â Â 
The Tomlinsons later visited the All American factory in North Carolina where they met with David Bridges, a regional sales manager and corporate representative of All American, and reviewed building plans.Â  Before the Tomlinsons left, they asked Bridges whether Mixon was an authorized dealer.Â  Bridges assured them he was.Â  Bridges also told the Tomlinsons All American had checked Mixon out and All American would â€œstand behind him.â€Â  The Tomlinsons then contracted to purchase the All American home through Mixon.Â  
After Mixon started construction, All American terminated its relationship with Mixon and never delivered the home to the building site.Â  Calls by the Tomlinsons to All American went unanswered.Â  All the while, the Tomlinsons, in reliance upon the contract, incurred various costs and expenses.Â  They were also threatened with liens against their property.Â Â Â  
When the Tomlinsons finally reached Bridges, he told them All American had dismissed Mixon as a builder and it would not build the home that the Tomlinsons had contracted to purchase.Â Â Â  
This suit followed with the Tomlinsons alleging, among other things, that they had entered into a contract with All American for the construction of the house in question.Â  
The trial judge advised in her charge to the jury that it was â€œto consider each [cause of action] as if the others donâ€™t exist,â€ that â€œthere is only one recovery for the wrong,â€ and that â€œat some particular point there will be a mechanism by which to make the appropriate award to the plaintiff[s].â€Â  She expressly instructed the jury that it was not to add any damages awarded on multiple claims â€œin order to provide recovery to the plaintiff[s].â€Â  
In a special interrogatory, the jury found Mixon to be All Americanâ€™s agent.Â  The jury returned a verdict in the amount of $46,149.00 on the Tomlinsonsâ€™ breach of contract claim and $73,416.67 on their negligent misrepresentation claim.[1]Â  The trial judge later denied a motion by All American to require the Tomlinsons to elect the remedy upon which they wanted to recover.Â  She then entered judgment on both claims, allowing the Tomlinsons to recover total damages in the amount of $119,565.67.Â  
We hold the trial judge erred in not requiring the election that All American sought.
Â In Save Charleston Foundation v. Murray,[2] this court said the following about the doctrine of election of remedies:

The doctrine of election of remedies involves a choice between two or more different and coexisting modes of procedure and relief afforded by law for the same injury.Â  Tzouvelekas v. Tzouvelekas, 206 S.C. 90, 33 S.E.2d 73 (1945); Walker v. McDonald, 136 S.C. 231, 134 S.E. 222 (1926); Boardman v. Lovett Enterprises, Inc., 283 S.C. 425, 323 S.E.2d 784 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Its purpose is to prevent double redress for a single wrong.Â  25 Am. Jur. 2d Election of Remedies Section 1 at 646 (1966).Â  Application of the doctrine should be confined to cases where double compensation of the plaintiff is threatened.Â  Id.Â  Section 3 at 650.Â  When an identical set of facts entitle the plaintiff to alternative remedies, he may plead and prove his entitlement to either or both; however, the plaintiff may not recover both.Â  Baeza v. Robert E. Lee Chrysler, Plymouth, Dodge, Inc., 279 S.C. 468, 309 S.E.2d 763 (Ct. App. 1983).Â  â€œThis rule rests on the principle that the plaintiff should have a full opportunity to prove his claim to some form of relief, but he should not receive a double recovery.â€Â  Id. at 473, 309 S.E.2d at 766.[3]  

For the doctrine of election of remedies to apply, therefore, two or more remedies must be available to the complaining party at the time of the election and these remedies must be inconsistent.[4]Â  An inconsistency exists where, if an election is not made, a party will receive a double recovery.[5]Â  
Here, the Tomlinsons recovered damages on claims of breach of contract and negligent misrepresentation.Â  These recoveries rest on the same set of facts, viz., that All American represented its dealer Mixon to be its agent;[6] that the Tomlinsons contracted with All American through its dealer and agent Mixon to manufacture a modular house and have it delivered to and constructed upon the Tomlinsonsâ€™ property on Lake Wateree; that All American failed to perform when it refused to deliver the house to the building site and complete the construction started by its agent, notwithstanding All American represented it would stand behind him; and that the Tomlinsons suffered damages as a consequence.Â  
To avoid a double recovery, the Tomlinsons, therefore, should elect on remand which one of the two claims they wish to recover their damages upon.[7]
REVERSED and REMANDED.
SHORT, J., concurs.Â  ANDERSON, J., dissents in a separate opinion.Â  
ANDERSON, J. (dissenting):Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I disagree with the reasoning and analysis of the majority.Â  The holding of the majority misconstrues and misapplies the law extant in regard to the doctrine of election of remedies.Â  I VOTE to AFFIRM the jury verdicts.
The jury rendered verdicts for Elwood Porter Tomlinson and Frances Goins Tomlinson (the Tomlinsons) against All American Homes of NC, LLC (All American) on a breach of contract claim in the amount of $46,146.00 and a negligent misrepresentation claim in the amount of $73,416.67.Â  All American contends the trial court erred as a matter of law in failing to require an election of remedies.Â  I disagree.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Tomlinsons, who reside in Charlotte, North Carolina, planned to build their retirement home on a lot near Lake Wateree, South Carolina.Â  In early 2001, the Tomlinsons contacted Kenneth Mixon, who worked as a manufactured home dealer, about a Cape Cod style home.Â  Mixon told the Tomlinsons about All American Homes, a manufacturer of pre-built, modular homes which are sold to authorized builders/dealers, who in turn sell them to the end customer.Â  The houses are made of wood, in sections, delivered to the sites and placed on foundations.Â  The customer must purchase a home through a dealer.
Mixon suggested the Tomlinsons go to the companyâ€™s factory.Â  A meeting was scheduled.Â  The Tomlinsons met with David Bridges, the regional sales manager for All American.Â  Mixon promised to meet them there, but he did not attend due to car trouble. Â At the meeting, All American approved proposed changes for the home and gave the Tomlinsons assurances concerning Mixon.Â  All American assured the Tomlinsons that Mixon had been checked out, he was an All American dealer in good standing, and Bridges would â€œstand behind him.â€Â  Bridges does not recall any discussions regarding Mixon. Â However, the Tomlinsons declared that Bridgesâ€™ assurances concerning Mixon affected their decision to proceed with the transaction.
The Tomlinsons appeared to have entered into a contract with Mixon on or about March 9, 2001, even though the meeting did not occur until later and Mixon had not yet been approved as a dealer for All American.Â  The Tomlinsons issued a check made payable to Pavillion Homes in the amount of $10,000 dated March 9, 2001.Â  The Authorized Builder Application of Mixon is dated April 23, 2001.Â  Bridges believed the meeting occurred after May 18, 2001. 
The assurances the Tomlinsons received at the meeting with All American only affected their going forward with building and not the entering into the contract itself.Â  Although unsigned by Mixon, the written agreement lists a pre-tax purchase price of $176,694.Â  The house model listed on the contract between the Tomlinsons and Mixon was not a Cape Cod style house, but rather a â€œSalt Box RSO.â€Â  This model was sold by Mixonâ€™s former company, Virginia Homes, but not by All American. 
The Tomlinsons obtained construction financing and work began on their house.Â  On August 15, 2001, All American agreed to sell the house to Mixon for $109,700.97 and received a $1,000 deposit from Mixon.Â  When construction slowed, the Tomlinsons tried to reach Mixon repeatedly.Â  The Tomlinsons confronted Mixon at his house and were told that someone else would finish the house.Â  All American had not initiated construction on the house because Mixon had not returned the required confirmation package, which consisted of a builder-approved floor plan and order contract.
On September 18, 2001, All American terminated Mixon as an authorized builder/dealer.Â  The Tomlinsons were not informed of Mixonâ€™s proposed termination and continued with the building of their house.Â  Mr. Tomlinson stated that if All American Homes had informed him of Mixonâ€™s termination when it happened, he would have â€œimmediatelyâ€ stopped the work that was being done on the site and the damages would have been limited at that point to $12,000.Â  According to Mrs. Tomlinson, â€œa lot of expenseâ€ would have been saved.Â  Prior to learning that Mixon was no longer a dealer with All American, the Tomlinsons withdrew approximately $32,000 on the construction loan.Â  That loan was refinanced, and other costs â€“ storage, marina rental, utilities at the site â€“ also accrued, for damages of approximately $60,000.
In April 2002, the Tomlinsons filed a complaint against Mixon d/b/a Pavillion Custom Homes and All American Homes of North Carolina, LLC, alleging breach of contract, third party beneficiary contract rights, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, constructive trust, constructive fraud, negligent misrepresentation, and violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act.Â  The Tomlinsons presented damages in excess of $130,000.
Following a default by Mixon, the case was tried against All American before a jury.Â  Only three claims remained at the close of trial: breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, and negligent misrepresentation.Â  In response to a special interrogatory, the jury found Mixon was an agent of All American.Â  The jury returned verdicts in favor of the Tomlinsons on the breach of contract claim, awarding $46,146.00, and the negligent misrepresentation claim, awarding $73,416.67.Â  On June 18, 2003, the trial court ordered post-trial motions and plaintiffâ€™s election of remedies to be filed within ten days. Â The Tomlinsons objected to an election.Â  The trial court ruled no election was required.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  The Doctrine of Election of Remedies
All American contends the trial court erred in denying its post-trial motion requesting an election of remedies.Â  I disagree.
The doctrine of election of remedies involves a choice between two or more different and coexisting modes of procedure and relief afforded by law for the same injury. Â Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 479 S.E.2d 35 (1996); Tzouvelekas v. Tzouvelekas, 206 S.C. 90, 33 S.E.2d 73 (1945); Cowart v. Poore, 337 S.C. 359, 523 S.E.2d 182 (Ct. App. 1999); Brown v. Felkel, 320 S.C. 292, 465 S.E.2d 93 (Ct. App. 1995); Jones v. Winn-Dixie Greenville, Inc., 318 S.C. 171, 456 S.E.2d 429 (Ct. App. 1995); Inman v. Imperial Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc., 303 S.C. 10, 397 S.E.2d 774 (Ct. App. 1990); see also Williams v. Riedman, 339 S.C. 251, 529 S.E.2d 28 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting that election of remedies involves a choice between different forms of redress afforded by law for the same injury or different forms of proceeding on the same cause of action).Â  Election of remedies is the act of choosing between different remedies allowed by law on the same set of facts.Â  Taylor, 324 S.C. at 218, 479 S.E.2d at 44-45; Harper v. Ethridge, 290 S.C. 112, 348 S.E.2d 374 (Ct. App. 1986).
The basic purpose behind the election of remedies doctrine is the principle that there can be no double recovery for a single wrong.Â  Brown, 320 S.C. at 294, 465 S.E.2d at 95; Harbin v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas, 316 S.C. 423, 450 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 1994); see also Cowart, 337 S.C. at 364, 523 S.E.2d at 185 (purpose of doctrine of election of remedies is to prevent double redress for a single wrong).Â  Use of the doctrine is limited to cases in which a double recovery by the plaintiff is threatened.Â  Adams v. Grant, 292 S.C. 581, 358 S.E.2d 142 (Ct. App. 1986); Save Charleston Found. v. Murray, 286 S.C. 170, 333 S.E.2d 60 (Ct. App. 1985).
When one set of facts entitles the plaintiff to alternative remedies, he may plead and prove his entitlement to either or both.Â  Save Charleston Found., 286 S.C. at 176, 333 S.E.2d at 64; Baeza v. Robert E. Lee Chrysler, Plymouth, Dodge, Inc., 279 S.C. 468, 309 S.E.2d 763 (Ct. App. 1983).Â  However, the plaintiff may not recover both.Â  Id. Â 
A defendant may raise the issue of election of remedies at any stage of the case.Â  Cowart, 337 S.C. at 364, 523 S.E.2d at 185.Â  Indeed, to carry out the doctrineâ€™s purpose, the trial judge should sua sponte require election if he lets both causes of action go to the jury.Â  Id.; Brown, 320 S.C. at 294, 465 S.E.2d at 95.Â  To hold otherwise would result in an impermissible double recovery.Â  Adamson v. Marianne Fabrics, Inc., 301 S.C. 204, 391 S.E.2d 249 (1990); Inman, 303 S.C. at 15, 397 S.E.2d at 777.
Election of remedies is not applicable where there are two separate causes of action, each based on different facts.Â  Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. at 218, 479 S.E.2d at 45; Jones, 318 S.C. at 175, 456 S.E.2d at 432; Robert Harmon and Bore, Inc. v. Jenkins, 282 S.C. 189, 318 S.E.2d 371 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  When applying the doctrine of election of remedies, courts examine the underlying facts in the causes of action and determine if different conduct supports distinct injuries.Â  See Taylor, 324 S.C. at 218, 479 S.E.2d at 45; Creach v. Sara Lee Corp., 331 S.C. 461, 502 S.E.2d 923 (Ct. App. 1998); Jones v. Winn-Dixie Greenville, Inc., 318 S.C. 171, 456 S.E.2d 429 (Ct. App. 1995).
In order to decide if the doctrine of election of remedies is applicable to the facts of the instant case, and because the application of the doctrine depends heavily on the specific facts of a case, I analyze prior precedent concerning election of remedies.
In Jones v. Winn-Dixie Greenville, Inc., 318 S.C. 171, 456 S.E.2d 429 (Ct. App. 1995), our court summarized the principles of election of remedies.Â  Jones brought an action against Winn-Dixie alleging slander, outrage, false imprisonment, and assault and battery after she had been forcibly detained at the store as a suspected shoplifter.Â  Id. at 174, 456 S.E.2d at 431.Â  The jury returned verdicts in the same amounts on the false imprisonment and assault and battery causes of action.Â  Id.Â  The trial court eliminated one of the awards under election of remedies, reasoning that the failure to do so would result in double recovery because Jones had essentially suffered one wrong.Â  Id.Â  In reversing that decision, this court explained:

The doctrine of election of remedies involves a choice between different forms of redress afforded by law for the same injury or different forms of proceeding on the same causes of action.Â  Stated another way, election of remedies is the act of choosing between different remedies allowed by law on the same set of facts.Â  Its purpose is to prevent double redress for a single wrong.Â  Where a party has asserted only one primary wrong, he is entitled to only one recovery.Â  However, the principle has no application where two separate causes of action, each based on different facts, exist.

Jones, 318 S.C. at 175, 456 S.E.2d at 432.Â  The court focused on the distinct elements of the differing causes of action in finding that â€œdistinctive injuries occurred at different times,â€ thus supporting each separate award against Winn-Dixie.Â  Id.
Our Supreme Court, in Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 479 S.E.2d 35 (1996), cited Jones in concluding the trial court erred in forcing an election of remedies.Â  Taylor brought suit for medical malpractice, complaining about the manner in which Dr. Medenica had handled the treatment of Taylorâ€™s breast cancer.Â  As a result of Dr. Medenicaâ€™s actions, Taylor was ineligible for alternative forms of chemotherapy.Â  At the time of trial, it was uncontested that her condition was terminal.Â  Id. at 210, 479 S.E.2d at 40.Â  Taylor sought to recover under negligence and unfair trade practices.Â  Id.Â  The jury returned substantial awards on both causes of action.Â  Id. at 219, 479 S.E.2d at 45.Â  The court enunciated that an election of remedies was not proper.Â  The court observed that the negligence cause of action was based on the provision of â€œreckless medical care,â€ while the Unfair Trade Practices Act claim was premised on billing for useless and unnecessary tests.Â  The court recognized that, because different conduct supports the UTPA and negligence claims, no election was required.Â  Id.
Creach v. Sara Lee Corporation, 331 S.C. 461, 502 S.E.2d 923 (Ct. App. 1998), is analogous to the case at hand.Â  Creach involved an action for negligence, breach of warranty, and strict liability for injuries suffered when Creach bit into a biscuit that contained a hard substance that injured her tooth.Â  Id. at 463, 502 S.E.2d at 924.Â  The jury found for Creach on all three causes of action and returned a verdict of $60,000 against Sara Lee.Â  Id.Â  The defense argued the verdict represented triple recovery and moved that the verdict be reformed.Â  The court confirmed no election was required because only one recovery was sought and only one recovery was awarded.Â  Id.Â  The court of appeals expressed its imprimatur with the jury charge by the trial court.Â  The trial court instructed the jury: â€œCreach was not entitled to multiple redress for a single wrong.â€Â  Id. at 464, 502 S.E.2d at 924.
The first inquiry in an election of remedies case is whether the causes of action involved different elements of proof, speak to facts occurring at different points in time, and are not simply two ways of describing a single wrong.Â  See Taylor, 324 S.C. at 218, 479 S.E.2d at 45; Creach, 331 S.C. at 464, 502 S.E.2d at 924; Jones, 318 S.C. at 175, 456 S.E.2d at 432.Â  Here, All American contends the Tomlinsons should elect between the remedies for breach of contract and negligent misrepresentation.Â  One cause of action, based in tort, addresses the circumstances and representations made prior to and after entering into the contract.Â  The other cause of action is in contract and applies to the failure to perform.
II.Â  Breach of Contract
The first remedy sought concerns breach of contract.Â  A binding, valid contract must exist for there to be a cause of action for breach of contract.Â  See Tidewater Supply Co. v. Industrial Elec. Co., 253 S.C. 483, 171 S.E.2d 607 (1969); Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003).
In order for a contract to be valid and enforceable, the parties must have a meeting of the minds as to all essential and material terms of the agreement.Â  Davis v. Greenwood Sch. Dist. 50, __S.C.__, 620 S.E.2d 65 (2005); Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 382 S.E.2d 891 (1989); see also Edens v. Laurel Hill, Inc., 271 S.C. 360, 364, 247 S.E.2d 434, 436 (1978) (â€œIt is well settled in South Carolina that in order for there to be a binding contract between parties, there must be a mutual manifestation of assent to the terms.â€).Â  The â€œmeeting of mindsâ€ required to make a contract is not based on secret purpose or intention on the part of one of the parties, stored away in his mind and not brought to the attention of the other party, but must be based on purpose and intention which has been made known or which, from all the circumstances, should be known.Â  Player, 299 S.C. at 105, 382 S.E.2d at 894.Â  â€œA contract exists where there is an agreement between two or more persons upon sufficient consideration either to do or not to do a particular act.â€Â  Benya v. Gamble, 282 S.C. 624, 628, 321 S.E.2d 57, 60 (Ct. App. 1984).
A contract is an obligation which arises from actual agreement of the parties manifested by words, oral or written, or by conduct.Â  Prescott v. Farmers Tel. Coop., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 516 S.E.2d 923 (1999); Gaskins v. Blue Cross-Blue Shield of South Carolina, 271 S.C. 101, 245 S.E.2d 598 (1978); Regions Bank, 354 S.C. at 661, 582 S.E.2d at 439.Â  These principles govern contract formation generally and specifically control the creation of a contract.Â  Hodge v. National Fidelity Ins. Co., 221 S.C. 33, 68 S.E.2d 636 (1952).
The necessary elements of a contract are offer, acceptance, and valuable consideration.Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 581 S.E.2d 161 (2003); Armstrong v. Collins, Op. No. 4028 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Oct. 3, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 38 at 41); see also Hughes v. Edwards, 265 S.C. 529, 220 S.E.2d 231 (1975) (stating for a contract to arise there must be an agreement between two or more parties and an offer, acceptance, and meeting of the minds of the parties involved).
A contract may give a right to demand performance, but no cause of action arises until a party refuses or neglects to perform some duty required by the terms of the contract.Â  See Tillinghast v. Boston & Port Royal Lumber Co., 39 S.C. 484, 18 S.E. 120 (1893), overruled on other grounds by Hendrix v. Hendrix, 296 S.C. 200, 371 S.E.2d 528 (1988).Â  Thus, a contract cannot give rise to a cause of action until there has been some breach of such contract.Â  Id.Â  A breach of contract is defined as a failure without legal excuse to perform any promise which forms the whole or part of a contract.Â  See Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 188 (6th ed. 1990).Â  A party breaches a contract when he does not perform as he agreed to perform under the contract.Â  A partyâ€™s contractual duty is found in the obligation assumed by the party to the contract.Â  Sechrest v. Forest Furniture Co., 141 S.E.2d 292 (N.C. 1965).Â  A partyâ€™s failure to comply with the contractual duty constitutes the breach.Â  Id.Â  Nonperformance of a valid contract is a breach thereof.
To recover for a breach of contract, the plaintiff must prove:

(1) a binding contract entered into by the parties;
(2) a breach or unjustifiable failure to perform the contract; and
(3) damage suffered by the plaintiff as a direct and proximate result of the breach.

Fuller v. Eastern Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 240 S.C. 75, 124 S.E.2d 602 (1962).Â  The general rule is that for a breach of contract the defendant is liable for whatever damages follow as a natural consequence and a proximate result of such breach.Â  Id.Â  Damages recoverable for breach of contract either must flow as a natural consequence of the breach or must have been reasonably within the partiesâ€™ contemplation at the time of the contract.Â  Manning v. City of Columbia, 297 S.C. 451, 377 S.E.2d 335 (1989); Kline Iron & Steel Co. v. Superior Trucking Co., 261 S.C. 542, 201 S.E.2d 388 (1973).
Damages in a breach of contract action are to place the nonbreaching party in the position he or she would have been had there been no breach and the contract was performed.Â  See Drews Co. v. Ledwith-Wolfe Assocs., Inc., 296 S.C. 207, 371 S.E.2d 532 (1988) (explaining that purpose of award of damages for breach is to give compensation, that is, to put plaintiff in as good a position as he would have been in had the contract been performed); Minter v. GOCT, Inc., 322 S.C. 525, 473 S.E.2d 67 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating purpose of damages for breach of contract is to put plaintiff in as good a position as he or she would have been if contract had been performed).Â  Damages give the nonbreaching party the benefit of his bargain.Â  South Carolina Fed. Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby Dev. Co., 303 S.C. 74, 399 S.E.2d 8 (Ct. App. 1990), affâ€™d, 310 S.C. 232, 423 S.E.2d 114 (1992).Â  The proper measure of damages for breach of contract is the loss actually suffered by the contractee as the result of the breach.Â  South Carolina Fin. Corp. v. West Side Fin. Co., 236 S.C. 109, 113 S.E.2d 329 (1960).Â  In the normal case, the damage will consist of two distinct elements: (1) out-of-pocket costs actually incurred as a result of the contract; and (2) the gain above costs that would have been realized had the contract been performed.Â  Collins Entmâ€™t, Inc. v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 611 S.E.2d 262 (Ct. App. 2005).
The breach of contract action in the instant case pertains to All Americanâ€™s failure to construct a home at the Tomlinsonsâ€™ property.Â  As the jury responded to the special interrogatory finding Mixon was an agent of All American, it is reasonable to conclude the jury therefore found All American responsible for breach of the contract entered into between the Tomlinsons and Mixon.Â  The Tomlinsons sought and recovered actual damages suffered as a result of All Americanâ€™s failure to manufacture, deliver, and/or install the Cape Cod Home on the property as contractually agreed.
III.Â  Negligent Misrepresentation
The negligent misrepresentation cause of action dealt with the meeting that took place in North Carolina between the Tomlinsons and All American. South Carolina courts have recognized the common law tort of negligent misrepresentation.Â  See Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 581 S.E.2d 161 (2003); Gilliland v. Elmwood Prop., 301 S.C. 295, 391 S.E.2d 577 (1990); Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 557 S.E.2d 676 (Ct. App. 2001); DeBondt v. Carlton Motorcars, Inc., 342 S.C. 254, 536 S.E.2d 399 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Thus, one may bring an action sounding in tort for negligent misrepresentation.
â€œA duty to exercise reasonable care in giving information exists when the defendant has a pecuniary interest in the transaction.â€Â  Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 474, 581 S.E.2d 496, 504 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Recovery of damages in a negligent misrepresentation action is based upon negligent conduct and predicated upon a negligently made false statement where a party suffers either injury or loss as a consequence of relying upon the misrepresentation.Â  Evans v. Rite Aid Corp., 324 S.C. 269, 478 S.E.2d 846 (1996); Gruber v. Santee Frozen Foods, Inc., 309 S.C. 13, 419 S.E.2d 795 (Ct. App. 1992); see also First Fed. Sav. Bank v. Knauss, 296 S.C. 136, 370 S.E.2d 906 (Ct. App. 1988) (recognizing that under appropriate facts, negligent representations inducing property purchase could be actionable); Pittman v. Galloway, 281 S.C. 70, 313 S.E.2d 632 (Ct. App. 1984) (holding negligent representation inducing the plaintiffâ€™s purchase of land is actionable).Â  A claim for negligent misrepresentation may be made when the misrepresented facts induced the plaintiff to enter a contract or business transaction.Â  Redwend, 354 S.C. at 474, 581 S.E.2d at 504.
To recover in a negligent misrepresentation action, a plaintiff must prove:

(1)Â Â Â Â  the defendant made a false representation to the plaintiff;
(2)Â Â Â Â  the defendant had a pecuniary interest in making the
statement;
(3)Â Â Â Â  the defendant owed a duty of care to see that he communicated truthful information to the plaintiff;
(4)Â Â Â Â  the defendant breached that duty by failing to exercise due
care;
(5)Â Â Â Â  the plaintiff justifiably relied on the representation; and
(6)Â Â Â Â  the plaintiff suffered a pecuniary loss as a direct and
proximate result of his reliance upon the representation.

Sauner, 354 S.C. at 407, 581 S.E.2d at 166; Armstrong v. Collins, Op. No. 4028 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Oct. 3, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 38 at 41); Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 42, 557 S.E.2d 676, 680-81 (Ct. App. 2001); DeBondt v. Carlton Motorcars, Inc., 342 S.C. 254, 266-67, 536 S.E.2d 399, 405 (Ct. App. 2000); AMA Mgmt. Corp. v. Strasburger, 309 S.C. 213, 222, 420 S.E.2d 868, 874 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  For purposes of proving negligent misrepresentation, evidence that a statement was made in the course of the defendantâ€™s business, profession, or employment is sufficient to prove the defendantâ€™s pecuniary interest in making the statement, even if the defendant received no consideration for it.Â  AMA Mgmt. Corp., 309 S.C. at 223, 420 S.E.2d at 874.
The negligent misrepresentation cause of action stems from the meeting in North Carolina where the Tomlinsons were told All American had investigated Mixon and All American would â€œstand behindâ€ him. The Tomlinsons sought and recovered actual damages suffered as a result of their reliance upon these representations given by All American regarding Mixonâ€™s dealership status.Â  The Tomlinsonsâ€™ reliance on those alleged misrepresentations was manifested in their decision to further deal with Mixon for the construction of their home and in continuing to do business with All American after Mixon failed to perform.Â  After analyzing the different elements of a breach of contract and negligent misrepresentation, and the facts underlying the causes of action in the instant case, it is luculent that the two causes of action involved separate injuries occurring at different times.
CONCLUSION
The evidentiary record is the quintessential example of damages irrefutably pertaining to different causes of action, i.e., a separate and distinct breach of contract claim and a negligent misrepresentation cause of action.Â  The breach of contract damages eventuated from All Americanâ€™s failure to deliver the home as ordered.Â  The damages emanating from the negligent misrepresentation cause of action arose from the Tomlinsonsâ€™ continued reliance on All Americanâ€™s relationship with
Mixon.
Mr. Tomlinson testified if All American Homes had informed him of Mixonâ€™s termination when it happened, the work would have â€œimmediatelyâ€ stopped on the site and the damages would have been limited at that point to $12,000.Â  According to Mrs. Tomlinson, â€œa lot of expenseâ€ would have been saved.Â  Prior to learning that Mixon was no longer a dealer with All American, the Tomlinsons withdrew approximately $32,000 on the construction loan.Â  That loan was refinanced, and other costs â€“ storage, marina rental, utilities at the site â€“ accrued, for damages of approximately $60,000.
Furthermore, All American knew or should have known the Tomlinsons were obtaining a construction loan and did not advise the Tomlinsons as to Mixonâ€™s status at All American.Â  As the preparation of the Tomlinson home site and foundation began, the Tomlinsons continued to incur expenses and were never informed that All American had terminated its relationship with Mixon and had no intention of delivering a home.Â  Mr. Tomlinson averred that after All American terminated Mixon as a dealer and failed to inform the Tomlinsons, Mixon continued to draw on the home loan and work continued on the house.Â  The Tomlinsons suffered damages in addition to the breach of contract damages as a result of this action.Â  The negligent misrepresentation in the instant case stemmed from the Tomlinsonsâ€™ continued reliance on All Americanâ€™s assurances even after Mixon had been dismissed, and in All Americanâ€™s failure to inform the Tomlinsons of Mixonâ€™s revocation as an All American dealer in order for the Tomlinsons to mitigate their damages.
The jury charges substantiated the conclusion that the causes of action involved different elements and created different damages.Â  In describing the damages flowing from the breach of contract claim, the trial judge stated:

Actual damages are intended to compensate that person and put them in as nearly as possible in the position that they would have been in before the breach occurred.
Actual damages would be the actual losses and expenses which have been suffered by the plaintiff because the defendant breached the contract.Â  Damages give the non-breaching party the benefit of his bargain.
In a normal case, that would consist of two distinct elements.Â  One would be the out-of-pocket expenses and costs that have actually incurred as a result of the contract and the other would be the gain above cost that would have been realized had the contract been performed. 
These damages must flow as a natural consequence of the breach or must have reasonably been within the contemplation of the minds of the parties at the time that the contract was made. 
In identifying the damages resulting from the negligent misrepresentation claim, the judge asseverated:
Finally, the plaintiff must prove that the plaintiff suffered a monetary loss as a direct and proximate result of the reliance on these statements.Â  What we mean by that is that it must have been reasonably foreseeable that the plaintiff would rely on the statement and that he would be caused harm as a result of relying on that particular statement.
Now, once you have determined whether or not the plaintiff has met those elements of the negligent misrepresentation then you would again consider the actual damages.Â  And again, actual damages are the actual losses and expenses that have been suffered by the plaintiff because of the actions of the defendant.Â  

The judge inculcated the jury to award ONLY damages resulting from the specific conduct concerning each cause of action on a separate and distinct basis.Â  As in Creach v. Sara Lee Corp., 331 S.C. 461, 502 S.E.2d 923 (Ct. App. 1998), the jury in the instant case was given clear instructions as to the differing theories of recovery.Â  There were no exceptions to the jury charge.
The trial court repeatedly instructed the jury that they were to consider each of the questions on the verdict form separately â€œas if the other claims did not exist.â€Â  Moreover, the trial court charged the jury that the law did not allow for multiple recoveries for the same wrong.Â  The judge commanded the jury to consider each cause of action separately.Â  All counsel approved the charge and complimented the trial court on the delivery of a comprehensive and comprehensible jury charge.
The jury returned verdicts on the breach of contract claim in the amount of $46,149 and on the negligent misrepresentation cause of action in the amount of $73,416.67.Â  The jury determined different damages and amounts of damages flowing from the separate injuries of breach of contract and negligent misrepresentation, bolstering the ruling that no election of remedies is required.Â  The verdicts of the jury are logically supported.Â  Attempting to determine the allocation of the differing elements of damage would be an egregious and offensive invasion of the province of the jury.
The actual damages ultimately presented and argued to the jury aggregated $131,985.21.Â  The combined verdict was $119,565.67.Â  All of the amounts were liquidated.Â  All American cannot argue that the amount awarded did not exceed the total actual amount presented.Â  The jury found, in considering the actions separately, that certain losses flowed from the negligent misrepresentation, while certain other losses were more properly attributable to the breach of contract.Â  Apodictically, the Tomlinsons did not receive double recovery.
I VOTE to AFFIRM the jury verdicts.Â  No election is mandated in this case.

[1] Although the juryâ€™s verdict for the breach of contract claim is $46,149.00 on the verdict form, slightly different amounts are contained in the record and in one of the briefs, but these discrepancies appear to be mere scrivenerâ€™s errors. 
[2]Â  286 S.C. 170, 333 S.E.2d 60 (Ct. App. 1985).
[3]Â  Id. at 175-76, 333 S.E.2d at 63-64.
[4]Â  25 Am. Jur. 2d Election of Remedies Â§ 16, at 776 (1996).
[5]Â  Id. Â§ 17, at 777-78.
[6]Â  During argument on the motion for a directed verdict, counsel for the Tomlinsons appeared to recognize that the question of whether Mixon was All Americanâ€™s agent served as the underpinning of its causes of action for breach of contract and negligent misrepresentation.Â  After counsel pointed to Bridgesâ€™s statement that All American would â€œstand behind Mixon and his work,â€ counsel said in reference to that statement:Â  â€œThatâ€™s the basis of [the] negligent misrepresentation claim.Â  Itâ€™s also the basis of the contract claim, because they say we will stand behind his work.Â  We make a promise.â€Â  
[7]Â  See Brown v. Felkel, 320 S.C. 292, 465 S.E.2d 93 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding the doctrine of election of remedies barred a plaintiffâ€™s claim against his accountant for the negligent promotion of his investments in, and loans to, another where the plaintiff earlier recovered from the accountant actual damages sustained as a result of the accountant making these investments and loans in an action premised on breach of contract).

description: Kevin Covert appeals his convictions for possession with intent to distribute cocaine in proximity of a school and trafficking in cocaine. Covert argues the trial court erred by denying his motion to suppress evidence due to a defective search warrant, allowing improper closing arguments, and using an unusual verdict form.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Kevin Covert, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4071
Heard November 7, 2005 â€“ Filed January 17, 2006


  
    
      
  Katherine Carruth Link, of West Columbia, for Appellant.
    Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Â Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

    SHORT, J.:Â  Kevin Covert appeals his convictions for possession with intent to distribute cocaine in proximity of a school and trafficking in cocaine. Covert argues the trial court erred by denying his motion to suppress evidence due to a defective search warrant, allowing improper closing arguments, and using an unusual verdict form.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS 
      Kevin Covert, Charles Henderson, and others were present in Covertâ€™s house in Greenville County when police searched it on September 26, 2002.Â  When the officers entered the house they found Henderson in the living room with a coffee grinder containing a white powder substance, small plastic bags of white powered substance, a cutting agent, sifting instruments, and an electronic scale, all in front of him on a coffee table.Â  A cell phone box on the couch next to him contained a large plastic bag of cocaine, weighing 441.50 grams.Â  Cocaine, weighing 22.89 grams, was found on the coffee table.Â  Two smaller quantities of cocaine, weighing 6.47 grams and 1.62 grams, were also recovered.Â  Police also found $1,950 on the floor in front of the couch.Â  Additionally, police found a pistol on a bookshelf.Â  Henderson was the only person in the living room.Â  Covert was found in a bedroom on the other side of the house.Â  A holster for a gun, a 9-mm. magazine, and several dozen rounds of ammunition were found in an adjacent bedroom that belonged to Henderson.
        All the individuals in the house were arrested and charged with trafficking in cocaine.Â  However, Covert and Henderson were also charged with possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Donald Myers and Roger Harris, both charged with trafficking, pled guilty to simple possession and were to receive suspended sentences in exchange for testifying for the State.Â  Myers testified he purchased cocaine from Covert and Henderson at the house numerous times.Â  Myers stated his purchases usually amounted to between one hundred and two hundred dollars each for between one and three-quarters grams and three and one-half grams of cocaine.Â  Myers also testified he had seen both Covert and Henderson bagging cocaine.Â  On September 26, Myers was at the house to purchase cocaine from Covert.
        Harris also testified he had purchased cocaine from Covert and Henderson at their house at least twice a week for the previous two years.Â  Harris stated Henderson sometimes delivered cocaine to his house.Â  Harris further testified that on the morning of September 26, Covert asked him to give him a ride to Atlanta.Â  Harris testified they drove to a bar in Atlanta where Covert met another individual.Â  Covert asked for Harrisâ€™s â€œelectronic door opener.â€Â  Covert returned about thirty minutes later and they drove back to Greenville.Â  Although the State attempted to establish that Harris drove Covert to Atlanta to obtain over 400 grams of cocaine, Harris did not see any cocaine during the trip. 
        After his arrest, Covert gave a statement to the police and admitted he purchased cocaine in Atlanta on September 26.Â  Covertâ€™s statement identifies his connection in Atlanta and details the activities of the trip.Â  Covert did not testify at trial.Â  On Hendersonâ€™s motion, Covertâ€™s statement was redacted to remove all references to Henderson and the edited version was read into the record.Â  Covert was tried together with his co-defendant, Henderson, and convicted of both charges.Â  Covert was sentenced to concurrent sentences of 25 years for the trafficking charge and 10 years for the distribution charge.Â  Covert now appeals.Â  
        LAW/ANALYSIS 
         I.     Suppression of Evidence
            Covert contends the trial judge erred by denying his motion to suppress evidence and by applying a good faith exception to the statutory warrant requirement because the warrant was defective.Â  We agree.Â  
            In criminal cases, an appellate court reviews errors of law only and is bound by factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â 
            â€œA courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.â€Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
            During the trial, Covert and Henderson moved to suppress evidence seized during the search on the basis that although the search was conducted on September 26, 2002, the magistrateâ€™s signature is dated September 28, 2002 on the warrant itself.Â  The magistrateâ€™s signature and the date of September 26, 2002 only appear on two separate pages of the affidavit.Â  During the trial, Detective Timothy Conroy testified that he did not see the magistrate sign the search warrant on the 26th and that â€œmost probably she didnâ€™t sign that night and that was brought back to her on some other occasion to sign.â€Â  Upon finding the warrant was defective under section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code (2003), the trial judge ruled a good faith exception to the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s exclusionary rule should apply to South Carolinaâ€™s statutory warrant requirement and denied the motion to suppress all evidence obtained during the September 26 search.
            First, we must determine whether the warrant was defective because the signature was dated two days after the search was conducted.Â  Section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code (2003) states that a warrant shall be â€œissued only upon affidavit sworn to before the magistrate, municipal judicial officer, or judge of a court of record establishing the grounds for the warrant.â€Â  Though the statute does not specifically require that the warrant be signed, it requires that it be â€œissued.â€Â  In Davis v. Sanders, 40 S.C. 507, 19 S.E. 138 (1894), â€œ[our supreme] court held that the warrant was not â€˜issuedâ€™ as required by law, and conferred no authority on the sheriff to make the arrest, because the magistrate did not sign at the foot as he intended to do, and because he did not intend the indorsement on the back as his signature of the warrant.â€Â 
            Du Bose v. Du Bose, 90 S.C. 87, 90, 72 S.E. 645, 646 (1911).Â  Therefore, a warrant is not issued until signed by an appropriate magistrate, municipal judicial officer, or judge of a court of record.Â  See 77-370 S.C. Op. Attâ€™y Gen. 295 (1977) (stating a warrant is properly issued only when signed by the magistrate and only upon a sworn affidavit).Â  Thus, the warrant in this case was defective because there was no evidence that the magistrate signed the warrant before the search was conducted and the signature on the warrant is dated two days after the search was conducted.
            Courts of other states have also held a search warrant must be signed because it is the confirmation that the magistrate determined the facts asserted in the affidavit support a finding of probable cause.[1]Â  In State v. Surowiecki, 440 A.2d 798, 799 (Conn. 1981), the Connecticut Supreme Court held that a warrant is not â€œissuedâ€ without a lawful signature on the search warrant by the person authorized to issue it.Â  The court reached this conclusion even though there was no doubt the judge intended to sign the search warrant and failed to do so because of a â€œmere oversight.â€Â  Id. at 798.Â  There are also several public policy considerations to support a requirement that the warrant be signed prior to a search: it impresses upon the magistrate the importance of his action in issuing a warrant; it discourages police misconduct by dictating that officers can not reasonably rely on an unsigned document as an authorization for conducting a search and by requiring officers to take corrective measures before they conduct a search; and it provides needed protections and assurances to persons in control of the property to be searched that the search has been authorized.Â 
            State v. Hentkowski, 397 N.W.2d 255, 258 (Mich. Ct. App. 1986).Â  Â Â 
            Having found the warrant was defective because the signature was dated two days after the search was conducted, we must next determine whether the good faith exception to the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s exclusionary rule should apply to South Carolinaâ€™s statutory warrant requirement.Â  The trial judge allowed the introduction of the evidence seized pursuant to a good faith exception as adopted by the United States Supreme Court in United States v. Leon, 468 U.S. 897 (1984).Â  The Leon rule applies when a search warrant is defective on Fourth Amendment grounds.Â  Id.Â  However, in this case, the evidence Covert sought to have excluded was obtained because of a defective search warrant based on a state statutory violation, not a constitutional violation.Â  
            In South Carolina, the statutory warrant requirement is separate and distinct from the prohibition in the federal and state constitutions against unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003); see U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.Â  In fact, as the South Carolina Supreme Court has recognized, section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code actually imposes stricter warrant requirements than the constitutional provisions.Â  See State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 121, 128, 536 S.E.2d 675, 678 (2000).Â  Therefore, the Leon good faith exception is not applicable to this case and we must determine whether there is a good faith exception to the statutory warrant requirement in South Carolina.
            In State v. Sachs, 264 S.C. 541, 559, 216 S.E.2d 501, 510 (1975), the Supreme Court of South Carolina found a good faith exception permits the introduction of evidence seized pursuant to a warrant that is defective under section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code if the officers have made a good faith attempt to comply with the affidavit requirement.Â  In Sachs, the affidavit the officers relied on contained misstated facts; however, the court determined that such misstatements in an affidavit were â€œnecessary hazardsâ€ encountered when federal and state authorities search in a joint effort and the affidavit satisfied a good-faith attempt to comply with the statute relating to search warrants.Â  Id.Â  
            In State v. McKnight, 291 S.C. 110, 112-13, 352 S.E.2d 471, 472 (1987), the officers orally recited the facts upon which the warrant was based, but no affidavit was ever executed. Â As a result, the court found that there was no good faith effort to comply with the statute; however, the court declined to decide whether there is a good faith exception for officers who execute a search with objectively reasonable reliance on a warrant that is ultimately found to be invalid.Â  Id. at 114, 352 S.E.2d at 473.Â  The instant case falls somewhere between the cases of McKnight and Sachs.Â  This is not a case of the â€œnecessary hazardsâ€ of obtaining a warrant as in the case of Sachs and it is not a failure to comply with the statutory warrant requirement as in McKnight.Â  Here, the officers failed to notice that either the magistrate did not sign the warrant on September 26 or that the signature on the warrant itself was misdated as September 28, while the search was conducted on September 26, 2002.[2]Â  The officers could have discovered either error by simply looking at the warrant itself; therefore, we find there was no good faith effort to comply with the statute.
            Because we find the warrant was defective and the good faith exception to the warrant requirement does not apply in this case, we must finally determine if the admission of the evidence found with the defective warrant constituted harmless error.Â  â€œError is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€Â  State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 193-94, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial error not affecting the result.Â  State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 409, 613 S.E.2d 760, 784 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The violation found in this case cannot be seen as harmless error because exclusion of the evidence could have reasonably affected the result of the trial and the issue of the amount of cocaine allegedly possessed by Covert was a central issue in this case. 
II.   
Trafficking Statute Covert claims the judge erred by submitting the actual text of the trafficking statute to the jury in written form.Â  We agree.
                This is a novel question of law in South Carolina; however, historically, as a common practice, trial judges in South Carolina have not given the actual text of a statute in written form to a jury.Â  The Court of Appeals of New York has ruled that the â€œconsent of defense counsel is an â€˜absolute preconditionâ€™ to furnishing the jury with the text of a statute because â€˜questions may arise concerning which sections of pertinent statutory material should be given to the jury.â€™â€Â  People v. Sanders, 70 N.Y.2d 837, 838 (N.Y. 1987) (citations omitted).Â  Therefore, we find that the judgeâ€™s submission of the actual text of the statute was in error because Covertâ€™s counsel did not consent to it being given to the jury.
                REVERSED AND REMANDED. Â 
                ANDERSON, J., concurs in a separate opinion.Â  GOOLSBY, J., dissents in a separate opinion.Â 
                ANDERSON, J., (concurring in a separate opinion):
                I VOTE to reverse the conviction and sentence of the appellant and to remand for a new trial because of the egregious error committed by the circuit judge in submitting a copy of the trafficking statute to the trial jury.
                PRESERVATION OF ERROR
                After the circuit judge charged the jury and sent them back to the jury room to begin deliberations, the judge asked whether there were any exceptions from the State or the defense.Â  

                Mr. Warder [counsel for Covert]:Â  Yes, sir.Â  Itâ€™s the procedure Iâ€™m beginning to object to.Â  Weâ€™ve now sent the jury out with a statute that providesâ€”
                 The Court:Â  Did theyâ€”
                 Mr. Warder:Â  â€”four ways toâ€”
                The Court:Â  I meant to take up all those papers.Â  Go get those papers from them.Â  Every paper I gave them.Â  Sir, go ahead.
                Mr. Warder:Â  Yes, sir.Â  We have a verdict form that in essence breaks the statute down in parts.Â  And, of course, for trafficking it gives them four different choices, all to find him guilty.Â  You know, I figure if we gave everybody enough choices, if we broke it down long enough we could have fifteen or twenty ways to find somebody guilty.Â  And I just think thatâ€™s highly prejudicial.
                You know, Iâ€™d really like to send a sheet out that had the presumption of innocence, and the burden of proof, and have it all broken down in one line sentences so they could read through and check, do you find that on each of them?Â  I mean, itâ€™s a way of highlighting the case to make it more likely that somebody will sooner or later check a yes.Â  And it seems to me that itâ€™s highly prejudicial.Â  
                It seems to me like the form in itself tends to keep going until thereâ€™s a high probability that somebody will think theyâ€™re supposed to find one of the four.Â  They have four things, and theyâ€™re asked for an amount four times.Â  And I think that the juryâ€™s going to think that theyâ€™re supposed to fill one of them in and write an amount in.Â  And I justâ€”I just think itâ€™s prejudicial.
                Mr. Abdalla:Â  Your honor, Iâ€™d like to be heard on that.Â  My position is Iâ€™d just rather have the indictment sent back as is with the way weâ€™veâ€”Iâ€™ve always thought it was guilty or not guilty.Â  And thatâ€™s just my position, your honor.
                The Court:Â  Well, we canâ€™t do that because the jury has to determine the amount.Â  So we canâ€™t just send the indictments in.Â  I note your exceptions.Â  I donâ€™t think by splitting it out into four is doing anything but making it easier for the jury to understand.Â  Theyâ€™re going to still have every bit of it.Â  And in a case like this, I canâ€™t conceive a jury deliberating without having a copy of the statute.Â  Itâ€™s very frequently that a copy of the statute is sent back in, or some portion of the charge that they request be in writing, or sometimes the entire charge is sent back in writing.
                Mr. Warder:Â  You know, Iâ€™ve heard of the entire charge being sent, but Iâ€™ve never heard of a court selecting the parts that they want to send back so it would be emphasized.Â  And Iâ€”
                The Court:Â  Well, Iâ€™ve explained to them itâ€™s not that Iâ€™m emphasizing, itâ€™s trying to help them understand.
                Mr. Warder:Â  I understand, but thatâ€™sâ€”
                The Court:Â  Now I donâ€™t bring them backâ€”I donâ€™t object to bringing them back out and telling them that, you know, they canâ€™t find them guilty of anything unless the State has proven that particular charge beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  But I donâ€™t see how there can be any doubt in their minds of that fact.
                Mr. Abdalla:Â  And, your honor, just for the record, Iâ€™ve joined in on Mr. Warderâ€™s objections.
                The Court:Â  All right.Â  Well, it seems the verdict form doesnâ€™t suit anybody but me.Â  But thatâ€™s the way itâ€™s going back.Â  Iâ€™m going to make the couple of corrections that we made at the bench a few minutes ago and that I explained to the jury while I was going through it.Â  And then Iâ€™ll let you gentlemen look at it to be sure weâ€™ve done that before I send it back.Â  And then Iâ€™ll have it sent back.Â  So weâ€™ll be at ease a few minutes.
                (Whereupon court was in recess)
                The Court:Â  All right.Â  I have made the changes that we talked about to the verdict form.Â  If either one of you want to look at it the bailiff has it.Â  Mr. Warder, the jury has already asked that I send into them the definition of the trafficking statute, the print form.
                 Mr. Warder:Â  Well, I meanâ€”
                The Court:Â  And I note your objection.
                Mr. Warder:Â  â€”itâ€™s predictable when we took it all to them.
                The Court:Â  Well, itâ€™sâ€”I think itâ€™s proper.Â  I think itâ€™s good.Â  I think it would be worse not to do it than to do it.Â  So I overrule your objection.  

                â€œThe general rule of issue preservation states that if an issue was not raised and ruled upon below, it will not be considered for the first time on appeal.â€Â  State v. Passmore, 363 S.C. 568, 583, 611 S.E.2d 273, 281 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 587 S.E.2d 691 (2003); State v. Lee, 350 S.C. 125, 564 S.E.2d 372 (Ct. App. 2002)).Â  Our courts have â€œconsistently refused to apply the plain error rule.â€Â  Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 306, 486 S.E.2d 750, 759 (1997) (citations omitted).Â  Instead, we have held: â€œit is the responsibility of counsel to preserve issues for appellate review.â€Â  Id.  
                Our supreme court, in Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000), explained the rationale behind this longstanding rule:Â  

                Imposing this preservation requirement on the appellant is meant to enable the lower court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and arguments.Â  The requirement also serves as a keen incentive for a party to prepare a case thoroughly.Â  It prevents a party from keeping an ace card up his sleeveâ€”intentionally or by chanceâ€”in the hope that an appellate court will accept that ace card and, via a reversal, give him another opportunity to prove his case.

                Id. at 422, 526 S.E.2d at 724 (citations omitted); see also Ellie, Inc. v. Micchichi, 358 S.C. 78, 103, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œWithout an initial ruling by the trial court, a reviewing court simply would not be able to evaluate whether the trial court committed error.â€). 
                The rule that an unpreserved issue will not be considered on appeal does have its exceptions.Â  Foremost is the axiomatic principle of law that lack of subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at anytime, including for the first time on appeal.Â  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 495 S.E.2d 773 (1998); State v. Richburg, 304 S.C. 162, 403 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â  Additionally, an exception exists where the interests of minors or incompetents are involved.Â  See Shake v. Darlington County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 306 S.C. 216, 219 n.2, 410 S.E.2d 923, 924 n.2 (Ct. App. 1991) (noting, in a termination of parental rights action, that â€œ[a]lthough it is questionable whether Mrs. Shake properly raised each of [the] grounds for termination at trial, we nevertheless address them all.â€); Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 536 S.E.2d 372 (2000) (approving the court of appealsâ€™ conclusion that procedural rules are subservient to the courtâ€™s duty to zealously guard the rights of minors); Caughman v. Caughman, 247 S.C. 104, 109, 146 S.E.2d 93, 95 (1965) (holding that â€œthe duty to protect the rights of incompetents has precedence over procedural rules otherwise limiting the scope of review.â€).
                Furthermore, our courts have developed the doctrine of futility, which recognizes that in circumstances where it would be futile to raise an objection to the trial judge, failure to raise the objection will be excused.Â  See State v. State, 344 So. 2d 248, 249 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1976) (noting the statute contained language stating that the magistrate shall â€œissue a search warrant signed by himâ€). 
[7]Â  See, e.g., State v. Weaver, 361 S.C. 73, 602 S.E.2d 786 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding a failure to observe the requirement that search warrants be executed and a return made within ten days after the date of the warrant does not invalidate the search); State v. Mollison, 319 S.C. 41, 459 S.E.2d 88 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating the failure to list on the return all the items seized or to make the return within ten days is a ministerial error that does not invalidate the search).
[8]Â  Article 1, section 10 of the South Carolina Constitution, which mirrors the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution, contains no signature and dating requirement.Â  S.C. Const. art. 1, Â§ 10. It requires only that the warrant issue â€œupon probable cause, supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, the person or thing to be seized, and the information to be obtained.â€Â  Id.
[9]Â  State v. Dawkins, 297 S.C. 386, 377 S.E.2d 298 (1989).
[10]Â  State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 530 S.E.2d 626 (2000).
[11]Â  See State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 543 S.E.2d 586 (Ct. App. 2001) (noting an appellate court will review an alleged error in the context of the entire record and may affirm under a harmless error analysis where there is overwhelming evidence of guilt), overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005). 
[12]Â  See, e.g., State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 18, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997) (holding the alleged impropriety of the solicitorâ€™s closing argument was not preserved for review where the trial court sustained an objection by defense counsel, but counsel did not move to strike or request a curative instruction); State v. McFadden, 318 S.C. 404, 458 S.E.2d 61 (Ct. App. 1995) (noting no error was preserved for review where the trial court sustained defense counselâ€™s objection to testimony and counsel made no further motion to strike the testimony). 
[13]Â  See State v. Myers, 344 S.C. 532, 544 S.E.2d 851 (Ct. App. 2001) (concluding the juryâ€™s use of a special verdict form did not prevent the jury from finding the defendant not guilty in light of the trial courtâ€™s instructions).
[14]Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 380, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œArguments not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review.â€).

title: McDill v. Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company
description: Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company and Nationwide Mutual Fire Insurance Company appeal the trial court's order that reformed automobile insurance policies issued to Moffet and Gerri McDill to add underinsured motorist coverage.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Moffet McDill, Gerri McDill, and Garrett McDill, a minor, Ryan Street, a minor, Edward Lee, a minor, Courtland Rogers, a minor, Defendants,
of whom Moffet McDill, Gerri McDill, and Garrett
McDill, a minor, are Respondents,
v.
Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company and Nationwide Mutual Fire Insurance Company,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4072
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed January 17, 2006

VACATED


  
    
      
J.R. Murphy, of Columbia, for Appellants.
William P. Hatfield and Robert D. McKissick, both of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company (Nationwide Mutual) and Nationwide Mutual Fire Insurance Company (Nationwide Fire) appeal from an order of the trial court reforming automobile insurance policies issued to Moffet and Gerri McDill to add underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage.Â  We vacate the trial courtâ€™s order on the basis of
mootness.
I.
On July 23, 2001, Garrett McDill, a minor, was seriously injured while driving a 1992 Honda Accord that collided with a car driven by Christopher Lawhon, also a minor.Â  The 1992 Honda Accord was owned and insured by Garrettâ€™s parents, Moffet and Gerri
McDill.  
The McDills filed this action on May 8, 2003, alleging neither Lawhon nor the vehicleâ€™s owner, Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc., had adequate insurance coverage to compensate for Garrettâ€™s injuries and alleging Lawhon was an underinsured driver under the laws of South Carolina.Â  The McDills sought to reform their own insurance policies issued by Nationwide Mutual and Nationwide Fire to include UIM coverage.Â  
By order dated January 14, 2004, the trial court found the defendants did not make a meaningful offer of UIM coverage as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002).Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to the McDills and ordered that their automobile insurance policies be reformed to include UIM coverage up to the liability coverage limits of $100,000 per person and $300,000 per accident.Â  This appeal followed.
By order of this court, we held the appeal in abeyance pending the resolution of a second lawsuit, McDill v. Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc., a tort action involving the determination of liability for the automobile accident in which the jury returned a verdict for the defendants.Â  The action was brought by Gerri McDill on behalf of herself and her son Garrett against Lawhon, as well as Lawhonâ€™s father, his grandfather, and his grandfatherâ€™s automobile dealership, Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc., which was the owner of the vehicle Lawhon was driving in the accident.Â  
Since we have affirmed the judgment finding no liability for the defendants in McDill v. Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc., Op. No. 4068 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Jan. 9, 2006), the question of UIM coverage has now become moot because our decision will have no practical legal effect upon the existing controversy.Â  As noted by our supreme court:Â  

An appellate court will not pass on moot and academic questions or make an adjudication where there remains no actual controversy.Â 
Jackson v. State, 331 S.C. 486, 489 S.E.2d 915 (1997).Â  Moot appeals differ from unripe appeals in that moot appeals result when intervening events render a case nonjusticiable.Â  See Jean Hoefer Toal, Shahin Vafai & Robert A. Muckenfuss, Appellate Practice in South Carolina 122 (1999).Â  â€œA case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon [the] existing controversy.Â  This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for [the] reviewing Court to grant effectual relief.â€ Mathis v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973).


    Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 567-68, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001) (alterations in original).
In the underlying tort case, a jury determined the McDills were not entitled to any damages from the owner or driver of the underinsured vehicle; therefore, we hold the McDills would not be entitled to UIM coverage under either Nationwide policy even if the policies were reformed to provide UIM coverage.Â  The Nationwide policies provided as follows:

We will pay damages . . . because of bodily injury suffered by you or a relative, and because of property damage.Â  Such damages must be due by law to you or a relative from the owner or driver of:Â  . . . an underinsured motor vehicle . . . .Â  

Thus, since the underlying tort action was decided adversely to the McDills, they are not entitled to UIM coverage because they are not entitled to damages from the driver of the underinsured motor vehicle.Â  Any opinion on whether the policies should be reformed would, therefore, be merely advisory.[1]Â  Cf. Empire Fire & Marine Ins. Co. v. Metro Courier Corp., 507 S.E.2d 525 (Ga. Ct. App. 1998) (holding an automobile insurerâ€™s declaratory judgment action to determine coverage issues, including the duty to defend, was moot once the insurer had denied coverage and refused to defend and a judgment was entered on the underlying suit because a court is not permitted to issue advisory opinions); see also In re Chance, 277 S.C. 161, 161, 284 S.E.2d 231, 231 (1981) (noting South Carolina appellate courts have â€œconsistently refrainedâ€ from issuing purely advisory opinions).
II.
Based on the foregoing, we vacate the trial courtâ€™s order in the current appeal that granted summary judgment to the McDills and reformed the policies to include UIM coverage.
VACATED.
SHORT, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  We note that, unless a party is trying to obtain coverage for an accident that has already occurred, litigation to reform an insurance policy to include UIM coverage would not be necessary.Â  Where there is no current accident and UIM coverage is desired, a party could simply add such coverage with an agent to protect against future losses.Â Â Â

title: Gillman v. City of Beaufort
description: Esther Gillman appeals the trial courtâ€™s ruling, dismissing her claim for negligence against the South Carolina Department of Transportation and the State of South Carolina.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Esther Gillman, Appellant,
v.
City of Beaufort, South Carolina, A Municipal Corporation; City of Beaufort Public Works Department; State of South Carolina and South Carolina Department of Public Transportation,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4073
Heard October 5, 2005 â€“Filed January 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Samuel L. Svalina, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
C. Scott Graber, of Beaufort, for Respondents.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â  Esther Gillman appeals the trial courtâ€™s ruling, dismissing her claim for negligence against the South Carolina Department of Transportation and the State of South Carolina.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On May 27, 2001, Gillman was walking along a sidewalk in Beaufort when she fell because the sidewalk was uneven.Â  On May 22, 2003, Gillman filed her initial complaint against the City of Beaufort, City of Beaufort Department of Public Works, St. Helenaâ€™s Parish, Inc., and the Protestant Church of the Diocese of South Carolina for injuries she sustained to her wrist and knee as a result of the fall.Â  All of the defendants answered on June 23, 2003 and each asserted that it did not own or exercise control over the sidewalk.Â  
After Gillman learned the sidewalk was located on a right of way owned by the South Carolina Department of Transportation, she filed a motion to join SCDOT and the State of South Carolina (collectively â€œthe Stateâ€) as an indispensable party pursuant to Rule 19, SCRCP.Â  On June 24, 2004, more than three years after the accident, the trial court ordered the State added as an indispensable party to the lawsuit because the State owned the sidewalk.Â  The trial court also granted summary judgment in favor of St. Helenaâ€™s Parish and the Protestant Church, and denied summary judgment to the City of Beaufort and the City of Beaufort Public Works Department.Â  Thereafter, on July 24, 2004, Gillman filed an amended summons and complaint adding the State as a defendant. Â 
The State filed a motion to dismiss, asserting the action was barred by the applicable statute of limitations.Â  On November 12, 2004, the trial court granted the motion to dismiss.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Gillman argues the trial court erred in dismissing her action against the State based on the statute of limitations.Â  We disagree.Â  
Rule 19, SCRCP allows a court to join, whenever possible, persons materially interested in an action so that a complete determination may be made.Â  Rule 19 states:Â Â Â  

(a) Persons to Be Joined if Feasible. A person who is subject to service of process and whose joinder will not deprive the court of jurisdiction over the subject matter of the action shall be joined as a party in the action if (1) in his absence complete relief cannot be accorded among those already parties, or (2) he claims an interest relating to the subject of the action and is so situated that the disposition of the action in his absence may (i) as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect that interest or (ii) leave any of the persons already parties subject to a substantial risk of incurring double, multiple, or otherwise inconsistent obligations by reason of his claimed interest. If he has not been so joined, the court shall order that he be made a party. If he should join as a plaintiff but refuses to do so, he may be made a defendant, or, in a proper case, an involuntary plaintiff.

Gillman argues that because Rule 19(a) does not contain an express limitation proscribing the courtâ€™s power to effectuate joinder of parties against whom the statute of limitations has run, the trial court must join a necessary party even if the statute of limitations would otherwise bar the claim.[1]Â  Gillman also assets that our supreme courtâ€™s decision in BancOhio Natâ€™l Bank v. Neville, 310 S.C. 323, 426 S.E.2d 773 (1993), indicates there is no limitation on a courtâ€™s power to add an indispensable party.Â  In BancOhio the supreme court ordered the State added as a party after an action was filed, tried, and heard on appeal because the State was a necessary party.Â  Id. at 329, 426 S.E.2d at 777.Â  BancOhio involved a property dispute concerning the closure of a roadway, and there was no statute of limitations which would have barred the claim against the State or limited the courtâ€™s power to add the State as a necessary party pursuant to Rule 19, SCRCP.Â  Id. at 328-29, 426 S.E.2d at 777.Â  Therefore, BancOhio is distinguishable from the case at bar because Gillman is asserting a negligence cause of action against the State, to which the South Carolina Tort Claims Act applies.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-110 (2005).Â  
The Tort Claims Act is a limited waiver of governmental immunity, and sets forth a maximum three-year statute of limitations in which negligence actions may be brought against the state.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-110 (2005)Â  (â€œExcept as provided for in Section 15‑3‑40, any action brought pursuant to this chapter is forever barred unless an action is commenced within two years after the date the loss was or should have been discovered;Â  provided, that if the claimant first filed a claim pursuant to this chapter then the action for damages based upon the same occurrence is forever barred unless the action is commenced within three years of the date the loss was or should have been discovered.â€) 
Â Under the discovery rule, the statutory limitations period begins to run from the date when the injury resulting from the wrongful conduct either is discovered or may be discovered by the exercise of reasonable diligence.Â  Cline v. J.E. Faulkner Homes, Inc., 359 S.C. 367, 371-72, 597 S.E.2d 27, 29 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The date when a plaintiff learns of a potential new defendant has absolutely no bearing on the timing of the statute of limitations.Â  Id. at 371, 597 S.E.2d at 29.
Our courts have not specifically addressed the question of whether an indispensable party may assert the statute of limitations as an affirmative defense when the party is joined pursuant to Rule 19, SCRCP, after the applicable statute of limitations has expired.Â  However, it is well established that the statute of limitations operates as a defense to limit the remedy available from an existing cause of action, and unless the action is commenced before the expiration of the limitations period, the plaintiffâ€™s claim is barred.Â  City of North Myrtle Beach v. Lewis-Davis, 360 S.C. 225, 230-31, 599 S.E.2d 462, 464 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Blyth v. Marcus, 322 S.C. 150, 152-53, 444 S.E.2d 512 (1994); see also Bagwell v. Hinton, 205 S.C 377, 393, 32 S.E.2d 147, 153-54 (1944) (holding, in a pre-rule decision, that a statute providing for the amendment of pleadings does not permit a court, under color of ordering an amendment, to abrogate the statute of limitations). 
We can find nothing in Rule 19 that prohibits a defendant from raising an affirmative defense, such as the statute of limitations, when a plaintiff attempts to join the party as necessary for a just adjudication.Â  Moreover, Rule 12(b), SCRCP, expressly permits a party to assert every defense, in law or fact, that he may have in responsive pleadings.Â  The parties agree that Gillmanâ€™s accident occurred on May 27, 2001.Â  Gillman did not serve the State until July 21, 2004, after the trial court ordered it joined as an indispensable party.Â  The State asserted the statue of limitations as a defense, and the trial court dismissed the claim because more then three years had elapsed between the date of the injury and the date the State was joined as a necessary party.Â  Because we can discern nothing that deprives a party joined under Rule 19 of any defense it may have, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant the Stateâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  Therefore, the order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Gillman does not argue that the amendment to her pleading adding the State as a party relates back to the date of the original pleading under Rule 15, SCRCP; therefore, we do not address that issue.Â
