title: Schnellmann v. Roettger
description: Affirms the grant of summary judgment for a listing agent on claims of negligent misrepresentation, fraud, and unfair trade practices, which were based on the contention she misstated the square footage of a residence for sale.
text:
Schnellmann v. Roettger


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Rick Schnellmann and Jennifer Schnellmann, Appellants,
v.
Nancy Roettger, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4074
Submitted 12/1/2005 â€“ Filed January 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephan Victor Futeral, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellants.Â  
Max G. Mahaffee, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Rick and Jennifer Schnellmann appeal the grant of summary judgment in favor of Nancy Roettger on claims of negligent misrepresentation, fraud, and unfair trade practices.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
In June of 2001, the Schnellmanns engaged Island Realty, Inc. to aid them in purchasing residential property in Mount Pleasant, South Carolina.Â  The Schnellmanns advised their chosen representative, Island Realty, that they wanted to purchase a home in excess of 3,000 square feet.Â  Roettger, who was affiliated with another real estate firm, was the listing agent for property located at 2958 Pignatelli Crescent.Â  Roettger advertised the property in the Charleston Trident Multiple Listing Service as having approximately 3,350 square feet.Â  Island Realty sent information about the property to the Schnellmanns, and the Schnellmanns entered into a purchase contract with the sellers.Â  Additionally, the Schnellmanns gave Island Realty power of attorney to act on their behalf regarding the purchase.Â  After closing, the Schnellmanns acquired information indicating the home was only 2,987 square feet, and this lawsuit ensued.[2]Â  The trial court granted Roettgerâ€™s motion for summary judgment on all claims.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Nexsen v. Haddock, 353 S.C. 74, 77, 576 S.E.2d 183, 185 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, the evidence and the inferences that can be drawn therefrom should be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Negligent Misrepresentation
To state a claim for negligent misrepresentation a plaintiff must show (1) the defendant made a false representation to the plaintiff; (2) the defendant had a pecuniary interest in making the statement; (3) the defendant owed a duty of care to communicate truthful information to the plaintiff; (4) the defendant breached that duty; (5) the plaintiff justifiably relied on the representation; and (6) the plaintiff suffered a pecuniary loss as a result of such reliance.Â  Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 473, 581 S.E.2d 496, 504 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The Schnellmanns argue that the trial court erred in concluding their reliance on Roettgerâ€™s representation was unreasonable and they suffered no damages.Â  We disagree. 
The record shows that the MLS listing for the property indicated the square footage given was an approximation â€œdeemed reliable but not guaranteed.â€[3]Â  The listing also included the following disclaimer:Â  â€œIF EXACT SQUARE FOOTAGE IS IMPORTANT TO YOU, MEASURE, MEASURE!â€Â  Furthermore, the sales contract granted the purchaser the privilege, and responsibility, to inspect the home prior to closing, the wording of the clause including specifically the homeâ€™s square footage.Â  A summary appraisal revealing the lesser square footage was performed prior to the closing.Â  A copy of the report was not requested by the Schnellmanns.Â  
It is well established that â€œthere can be no liability for casual statements, representations as to matters of law, or matters which plaintiff could ascertain on his own in the exercise of due diligence.â€Â  Robertson v. First Union Natâ€™l Bank, 350 S.C. 339, 348, 565 S.E.2d 309, 314 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting West v. Gladney, 341 S.C. 127, 134, 533 S.E.2d 334, 337 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  The Schnellmanns could have discovered the misstatement by simply requesting a copy of the appraisal or by having someone come in to measure the property.Â  They were informed via the MLS listing that the measurements were not precise.Â  The Schnellmanns viewed the house, and proceeded with the purchase without finally determining the exact square footage.Â  In light of the evidence presented, we agree with the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that if the Schnellmanns relied on the approximation of the square footage contained in the listing, such reliance was unreasonable as a matter of law.Â  
We also agree with the trial courtâ€™s conclusions that the Schnellmanns suffered no damages as a result of the misstatement.Â  As previously discussed, the property was appraised at the time of purchase and possibly again several months later as part of a refinancing.[4]Â  The appraisals report a value more than the $478,000 purchase price paid by the Schnellmanns and reflect the square footage of the home is less than 3,000 square feet.Â  The Schnellmanns walked through the property prior to the purchase and agreed to pay the $478,000 purchase price.Â  Dr. Schnellmann testified, and his wife agreed, they were not arguing the value of the home at the time of purchase was less than what they paid.Â  

Q.  And I understand from your direct testimony or, Iâ€™m sorry, your earlier testimony to Mr. Mahaffee, that youâ€™re not arguing with whether or not the house is in fact worth or was, at the time of sale, worth $478,000.Â  You argue and contest the square footage.
A.  Correct.
Q.  But not the value.
A.  Uh, yes.
Q.  Is that correct?
A.  Yes.

Considering this evidence and testimony, the trial court properly concluded there was no genuine issue of material fact regarding the issue of damages.Â  
II.Â  Fraud
The trial court likewise granted Roettgerâ€™s request for summary judgment as to fraud based on the Schnellmannsâ€™ unreasonable reliance and lack of injury.Â  To establish a claim of fraud, plaintiffs must show by clear and convincing evidence (1) a representation; (2) its falsity; (3) its materiality; (4) knowledge of its falsity or a reckless disregard for its truth or falsity; (5) intent that the plaintiff act upon the representation; (6) the hearerâ€™s ignorance of its falsity; (7) the hearerâ€™s reliance on its truth; (8) the hearerâ€™s right to rely thereon; and (9) the hearerâ€™s consequent and proximate injury.Â  King v. Oxford, 282 S.C. 307, 311, 318 S.E.2d 125, 127 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  The Schnellmannsâ€™ inability to establish the last two of the nine requisite elements of fraud make the trial courtâ€™s award of summary judgment entirely appropriate.Â  See Oâ€™Shields v. Southern Fountain Mobile Homes, Inc., 262 S.C. 276, 281, 204 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1974) (â€œFailure to prove any one of the . . . elements [of fraud] is fatal to recovery.â€).Â  
III.Â  Unfair Trade Practices
Finally, the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Roettger on the unfair trade practices claim because the acts complained of did not affect the public interest nor result in a pecuniary injury to the Schnellmanns.Â  â€œThe statute clearly requires that in order to recover pursuant to the UTPA one must prove . . . : 1) a violation of the Act [by the commission of an unfair or deceptive act in trade or commerce], 2) proximate cause, and 3) damages.â€Â  Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 318 S.C. 471, 482, 458 S.E.2d 431, 438 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  To be associated with trade or commerce, a defendantâ€™s acts must impact the public interest.Â  Daisy Outdoor Adver. Co. v. Abbott, 322 S.C. 489, 493, 473 S.E.2d 47, 49 (1996).Â  An impact on the public interest may be shown if the acts or practices have the potential for repetition.Â  Crary v. Djebelli, 329 S.C. 385, 387, 496 S.E.2d 21, 23 (1998).Â  The potential for repetition may be shown by proving that the same kind of actions occurred in the past or by showing that the procedures employed by the defendant create a potential for repetition of the deceptive practices.Â  Id. at 388, 496 S.E.2d at
23. In the present case, there was no evidence presented that Roettger had misstated square footage in MLS listings in the past or that any procedure regularly employed by her would cause this misstatement to be made again.Â  Even if a public impact had been shown, the Schnellmanns, as discussed above, suffered no pecuniary loss.
For all of the foregoing reasons, the ruling of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  A second measurement taken by the Schnellmannsâ€™ expert revealed the square footage of the house was closer to 3,087 square feet.Â  
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  The listing stated:Â  Apx SqFt:Â  3,350. 
[4] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Dr. Schnellmann was uncertain whether the appraisal he saw indicating the home was less than 3,000 square feet was performed at the time of the closing or a subsequent appraisal performed at the time of refinancing.Â

title: State v. Douglas
description: In this criminal case, Appellant was indicted for the offenses of criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree and committing a lewd act upon a minor.  The jury was unable to reach a verdict on the charge of criminal sexual conduct with a minor; however, the appellant was found guilty of committing a lewd act upon a minor. On appeal, Appellant presents two issues: (1) whether the circuit judge erred by qualifying a police officer in the field of â€œforensic interviewingâ€; and (2) whether the circuit judge erred in refusing to allow testimony that the alleged child victim had lied in the past.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
William R. Douglas, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4075
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed January 23, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor C. Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â William R. Douglas (Douglas) was convicted of committing a lewd act upon a minor and sentenced to twelve years.Â  On appeal, Douglas argues the trial court erred in admitting the testimony of Gwen L. Herod as an expert in forensic interviewing and in disallowing the testimony of Amelia Douglas that the victim lied to her in the past.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In February of 2003, Cathryn Douglas and her daughter (the victim) talked about â€œthe birds and the bees.â€Â  Cathryn told the victim â€œabout sex, [the] difference between [a] man and woman . . ., and not to do things with the man and if a man was to touch her for her to come out and say.â€Â  At that time, the victim informed Cathryn that Douglas, Cathrynâ€™s husband, had â€œdone that to her.â€Â  The victim advised Cathryn that Douglas had touched her inappropriately during the summer and fall of 2002, when she was seven years old.Â  Cathryn called the victimâ€™s grandmother, with whom the victim lived.Â  The victim told her grandmother what occurred.Â  Victimâ€™s grandmother notified the Sumter County Sheriffâ€™s Department.
On February 10, 2003, Officer Doris McGee, the investigator assigned to the case, contacted the victimâ€™s grandmother and asked to see the victim as soon as possible.Â  That same day, the victim was interviewed by Gwen L. Herod, a victim assistance officer with the Sumter County Sheriffâ€™s Office. App. 1997).Â  Herod had previously been qualified in family court, circuit court and federal court as an expert witness in interviewing child sexual assault victims.Â  She received specialized training on the RATAC method, which is used on a nationwide basis and is nationally recognized for interviewing child victims of sexual crimes.Â  After completing the initial RATAC training course, Herod was certified as a forensic interviewer using that method.Â  Herod receives a monthly national newsletter that informs her of current issues and case law regarding the RATAC method.Â  The trial court had sufficient evidence that forensic interviewing was a recognized field.Â  See State v. Jones, 273 S.C. 723, 259 S.E.2d 120 (1979); see also In re A.H., 578 S.E.2d 247, 250 (Ga. Ct. App. 2003) (rejecting claim that investigator was incompetent to conduct interview of child victim, noting he â€œemployed a known method for interviewing child victims, the RATAC methodâ€).
E.Â  Harmless Error
Even if the trial court had erred, we would hold this error to be harmless.
Whether an error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the particular case.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003); State v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 508 S.E.2d 870 (1998); State v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 575 S.E.2d 77 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  No definite rule of law governs this finding.Â  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 62 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 336 S.E.2d 150 (1985).
Error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial. Â In re Harvey, 355 S.C. at 63, 584 S.E.2d at 897; State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 613 S.E.2d 760 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Where a review of the entire record establishes the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction should not be reversed.Â  State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 609 S.E.2d 572 (Ct. App. 2005); Thompson, 352 S.C. at 562, 575 S.E.2d at 83.Â  Error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt where it did not contribute to the verdict obtained.Â  Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 420 S.E.2d 834 (1992).
Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â  State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 377 S.E.2d 581 (1989); Adams, 354 S.C. at 381, 580 S.E.2d at 795.Â  The admission of improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other evidence.Â  State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 577 S.E.2d 445 (2003); State v. Braxton, 343 S.C. 629, 541 S.E.2d 833 (2001); State v. Blackburn, 271 S.C. 324, 247 S.E.2d 334 (1978); State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 523 S.E.2d 787 (Ct. App. 1999); see also State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 469 S.E.2d 49 (1996) (instructing that error in admission of evidence is harmless where it is cumulative to other evidence which was properly admitted).
The only reasonable inference the jury could have drawn from Herodâ€™s testimony is that she believed the victim told the truth about being sexually assaulted.Â  However, Saunders testified her examination revealed tearing and scarring consistent with past penetration.Â  Douglas has not shown a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by Herodâ€™s testimony.
II.Â  BOLSTERING
Douglas maintains Herodâ€™s testimony impermissibly bolstered the victimâ€™s testimony.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note the State argues this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Unless an objection is made at the time evidence is offered and a final ruling made, the issue is not preserved for review.Â  See State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 479 S.E.2d 57 (1996); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993); Bank v. North Carolina Mut. Life Ins. Co., 186 S.C. 394, 195 S.E. 649 (1938).Â  A party must object at the first opportunity to preserve an issue for review.Â  State v. Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 509 S.E.2d 811 (1999); State v. Williams, 303 S.C. 410, 401 S.E.2d 168 (1991); State v. Lopez, 352 S.C. 373, 574 S.E.2d 210 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Yet, this rule does not require defense counsel to harass the judge by making continued objections after the trial court has ruled upon the issue.Â  See Dunn v. Charleston Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 311 S.C. 43, 426 S.E.2d 756 (1993); Long v. Norris & Assocs., Ltd., 342 S.C. 561, 538 S.E.2d 5 (Ct. App. 2000); State v. Holliday, 333 S.C. 332, 509 S.E.2d 280 (Ct. App. 1998); State v. McDaniel, 320 S.C. 33, 462 S.E.2d 882 (Ct. App. 1995).
Here, Douglas objected to Herodâ€™s testimony and the trial court held an in camera hearing to qualify the witness.Â  During the hearing, Douglas objected and argued Herodâ€™s testimony improperly bolstered the victimâ€™s testimony.Â  The trial court overruled this objection.Â  When the State moved the court to qualify the witness as an expert before the jury, Douglas renewed his objections. The trial court noted the objections â€œwill run throughout the record.â€Â  Therefore, Douglas properly preserved this issue for our review.
Improper bolstering occurs when an expert witness is allowed to give his or her opinion as to whether the complaining witness is telling the truth, because that is an ultimate issue of fact and the inference to be drawn is not beyond the ken of the average juror.Â  Maddox v. State, 622 S.E.2d 80 (Ga. Ct. App. 2005).
In State v. Barrett, the trial court allowed a social worker â€œto testify to the details of what [a v]ictim [of sexual abuse] had told her concerning the incident.â€Â  Barrett, 299 S.C. 485, 486, 386 S.E.2d 242, 243 (1989).Â  On appeal, defendant argued this testimony impermissibly bolstered the victimâ€™s testimony.Â  The supreme court explicated:

Ordinarily, when a witness has not been impeached, evidence of prior consistent statements is inadmissible. To this rule is an exception in criminal sexual conduct cases. When the victim testifies, evidence from other witnesses that she complained of the sexual assault is admissible as corroboration of the incident;
however, the evidence must be limited to the time and place of the assault, and may not include particulars or details. 

Id. at 486-87, 386 S.E.2d at 243 (citations omitted).Â  The court reversed the conviction because the social worker â€œtestified extensively to details of the sexual abuse reported by Victim.â€Â  Id. at 487, 386 S.E.2d at 243.
 State v. Jolly, 304 S.C. 34, 402 S.E.2d 895 (Ct. App. 1991), is instructive.Â  In Jolly, a social worker testified only that the victim told her the defendant â€œmessed with her.â€Â  Jolly, 304 S.C. at 36, 402 S.E.2d at 896.Â  The court of appeals distinguished Barrett and held that, because the social worker in Jolly did not provide extensive details of the incident, the testimony did not impermissibly bolster the victimâ€™s testimony.Â  Id. at 39, 402 S.E.2d at 898.
In the case sub judice, Herodâ€™s testimony is less bolstering than in both Barrett and Jolly.Â  Herod testified only about the time period in which the alleged events occurred, and opined that the victim needed a medical evaluation.Â  Although the jury could infer Herod thought the victim told her the truth about being molested, Herod offered no testimony as to the alleged perpetrator or the particulars of the sexual abuse.Â  Herod did not express her opinion as to whether or not the victim told her the truth during the interview.
Moreover, the testimony was not presented to bolster the victimâ€™s credibility, but as a measure to prevent a defense or argument that the victimâ€™s testimony was the result of police suggestiveness.Â  The RATAC method was developed in response to concerns about child victimsâ€™ testimony being tainted by police suggestiveness, as exemplified by State v. Michaels, 642 A.2d 1372 (N.J. 1994):

[A] sufficient consensus exists within the academic, professional, and law enforcement communities, confirmed in varying degrees by courts, to warrant the conclusion that the use of coercive or highly suggestive interrogation techniques can create a significant risk that the interrogation itself will distort the childâ€™s recollection of events, thereby undermining the reliability of the statements and subsequent testimony concerning such events.

Id. at 1379.
The trial court correctly found Herodâ€™s testimony did not impermissibly bolster the testimony of the victim.
III.Â  RULE 403, SCRE
Douglas alleges the trial court erred in failing to exclude Herodâ€™s testimony â€œbecause its probative value was substantially outweighed by its unduly prejudicial effect.â€Â  We disagree.
Rule 403, SCRE, provides:

Although relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.

See also State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 377, 401 S.E.2d 146 (1991).Â  Unfair prejudice means an undue tendency to suggest a decision on an improper basis, commonly, though not necessarily, an emotional one.Â  State v. Sweat, 362 S.C. 117, 606 S.E.2d 508 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The determination of prejudice must be based on the entire record and the result will generally turn on the facts of each case.Â  State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 609 S.E.2d 572 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in exceptional circumstances.Â  State v. McLeod, 362 S.C. 73, 606 S.E.2d 215 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We review a trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding Rule 403 pursuant to the abuse of discretion standard and are obligated to give great deference to the trial courtâ€™s judgment.Â  McLeod, 362 S.C. at 81-82, 606 S.E.2d at 220; State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 598 S.E.2d 279 (Ct. App. 2004). 
Here, Douglas argues Herodâ€™s testimony impermissibly bolstered the victimâ€™s testimony and unfairly prejudiced Douglas.Â  Herodâ€™s testimony did not impermissibly bolster the victimâ€™s testimony.Â  Douglas has not offered any â€œexceptional circumstancesâ€ for this court to reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value of Herodâ€™s testimony and its prejudicial effect on Douglasâ€™ case.Â  The trial court properly admitted Herodâ€™s testimony pursuant to Rule 403, SCRE.
IV.Â  VICTIM IMPEACHMENT TESTIMONY
Douglas avers the trial court erred in not allowing him to impeach the victim with extrinsic evidence in the form of his motherâ€™s testimony.
The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002); State v. Staten, 364 S.C. 7, 610 S.E.2d 823 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  An abuse of discretion arises from an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.Â  State v. Irick, 344 S.C. 460, 545 S.E.2d 282 (2001); State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 577 S.E.2d 460 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In order for an error to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant.Â  See Rule 103, SCRE; State v. Crocker, 366 S.C. 394, 621 S.E.2d 890 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 613 S.E.2d 381 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. McLeod, 362 S.C. 73, 606 S.E.2d 215 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Error without prejudice does not warrant reversal.Â  State v. King, Op. No. 4045 (S.C. Ct. App. filed November 21, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 44 at 35).

Rule 613(b), SCRE, reads:
Â 
  Extrinsic evidence of a prior inconsistent statement by a witness is not admissible unless the witness is advised of the substance of the statement, the time and place it was allegedly made, and the person to whom it was made, and is given the opportunity to explain or deny the statement. Â If a witness
does not admit that he has made the prior inconsistent statement, extrinsic evidence of such statement is admissible.

In the present case, the victim admitted to lying in the past, and generally admitted lying to Amelia Douglas, Douglasâ€™ mother.Â  However, on cross-examination, defense counsel asked: â€œDo you remember not telling the truth to Ms. Douglas before right?â€Â  The victim replied: â€œI told the truth to her.â€Â  Defense counsel inquired: â€œDo you remember telling her that you didnâ€™t cut a cord that you cut?â€Â  The victim responded: â€œNo.â€ 
During the presentation of his case, Douglas called Amelia to testify.Â  When Amelia began testifying as to an incident in which the victim lied about cutting a wire in the house but later admitted to cutting the wire, the State objected.Â  The trial court sustained the objection, but allowed Douglas to proffer Ameliaâ€™s testimony.Â  The court ruled the testimony was not admissible as a prior inconsistent statement of a witness under Rule 613(b), SCRE, because the alleged prior statement was not inconsistent with the victimâ€™s testimony.Â  Additionally, the trial court held the statement inadmissible under Rule 608(b), SCRE, which deals with specific instances of conduct.Â  In his brief on appeal, Douglas argues the victimâ€™s â€œtrial testimony was inconsistent with . . . her prior inconsistent admission of lying to [Amelia].â€
The trial court did not abuse its discretion in finding Ameliaâ€™s testimony about what the victim told her was consistent with the victimâ€™s testimony at trial that she had lied to Amelia in the past.Â  The judge properly found this was â€œnot a matter under [Rule 613(b)] where it is extrinsic evidence of a prior inconsistent statement of a witness because the witness, and that is the victim in this case, did not make an inconsistent statement, she actually admitted . . . she did . . . not tell the truth sometimes.â€Â  Further, the judge did not err in excluding the testimony pursuant to Rule 608(b).
Assuming arguendo the trial judge erred in prohibiting Ameliaâ€™s testimony, we find such error was harmless.
Error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003); State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 613 S.E.2d 760 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result. State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Where a review of the entire record establishes the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction should not be reversed.Â  State v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 466 S.E.2d 364 (1996); State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 609 S.E.2d 572 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 561 S.E.2d 640 (Ct. App. 2002).
If it did not contribute to the verdict obtained, then error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. Fletcher, 363 S.C. at 248, 609 S.E.2d at 586; Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 420 S.E.2d 834 (1992).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of
the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached. State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 377 S.E.2d 581 (1989); Adams, 354 S.C. at 381, 580 S.E.2d at 795. 
Even if the judge erred in excluding this testimony, the error is harmless because the victim admitted to lying to Amelia in the past.
CONCLUSION
We hold that FORENSIC INTERVIEWING is a recognized field of expertise.Â  We rule that Herod is qualified as an expert in forensic interviewing by virtue of her knowledge, skill, experience, training, and education. Â The judge did not err in allowing Herod to testify as an expert witness in the area of forensic interviewing.Â Â Â  Herodâ€™s testimony satisfied Rule 702, SCRE.Â  The judge properly concluded Herodâ€™s testimony would explain to the jury Herodâ€™s role in the process and Herodâ€™s decision to recommend a medical examination. 
We find the testimony of Amelia does not meet the test of the victim impeachment rule in South Carolina.Â  The trial court correctly exercised discretion in excluding Ameliaâ€™s testimony.
Accordingly, Douglasâ€™ conviction and sentence are
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: State v. Middleton
description: In this criminal case, the court concludes that the crawl space of a commercial building is a part of the "building" for purposes of the burglary statute.
text:
State v. Middleton


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Craig Middleton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4076
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 23, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Craig Middleton was convicted of second-degree burglary and safecracking and sentenced to concurrent terms of ten years.Â  Middleton appeals the burglary conviction, arguing he was entitled to a directed verdict.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On a Saturday night in April 2003, Officer Robert Bilyard, a police officer for the Town of Port Royal, responded to a telephone call about a burglar alarm at Henry J. Lee Distributors.[2]Â  Bilyard and another officer arrived at the scene and met Senis Hodges, a Lee employee.Â  The door to the main building was unlocked, and there was no sign of forced entry.Â  The alarms and telephones in the main office were inoperable, and the bolts that secured the office safe to the floor had been cut.Â  Hodges testified the safe contained a very large sum of money including over $100,000 in proceeds from sales at a golf tournament.Â  The contents of the safe were undisturbed, except pieces of the bolts that had been cut were pushed up into the safe.Â  
As Bilyard and Hodges left the building, they noticed the metal cover to the crawl space entrance was not in place.Â  The crawl space does not provide direct access to the building.Â  Officer Ronald Wekenmann, also of the Town of Port Royal police department, arrived on the scene and, as he approached the entrance to the crawl space, he saw Middleton hiding underneath the building near the crawl space trapdoor.Â  Wekenmann apprehended Middleton, who was wearing torn latex gloves and was carrying a ski mask.Â  
Another police officer investigated the crawl space and found numerous cut wires, torn insulation, a piece of a safe bolt, and a blue backpack containing latex gloves, wire cutters, and numerous other tools.Â  Outside the crawl space, the officer found a flashlight, keys, and a cell phone.Â  After being advised of his rights, Middleton stated:Â  â€œYou caught me; I did what I did and thatâ€™s all I have to say.â€Â  
At trial, Middleton moved for a directed verdict on the burglary charge arguing there was no evidence of entry into the office building.Â  The State argued the crawl space was part of the curtilage of the building.Â  The trial court found there was circumstantial evidence of a break-in into the office, the crawl space was part of the building, and Middleton was not entitled to a directed verdict on the burglary charge.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the denial of a directed verdict motion, the evidence is viewed in the light most favorable to the State to determine if any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence exists that reasonably tends to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 349, 529 S.E.2d 526, 527 (2000).Â  The court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Middleton argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for directed verdict on the burglary charge because the crawl space underneath the building does not meet the statutory definition of a â€œbuildingâ€ for purposes of the burglary statute.Â  We disagree.Â  
Middleton was charged with second-degree burglary in violation of South Carolina Code section 16-11-312(B), which provides in part:


(B)Â  A person is guilty of burglary in the second degree if the person enters a building without consent and with intent to commit a crime therein, and either:
  
. . .
  
(3) Â The entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.

S.C.Â  Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-312 (B) (2003).Â  As relates to the burglary statute, a building is defined in section 16-11-310: 

For purposes of Â§Â§ 16-11-311 through 16-11-313:
  
(1) â€œBuildingâ€ means any structure, vehicle, watercraft, or aircraft:
(a) Where any person lodges or lives; or
(b) Where people assemble for purposes of business, government, education, religion, entertainment, public transportation, or public use or where goods are stored.Â  Where a building consists of two or more units separately occupied or secured, each unit is deemed both a separate building in itself and a part of the main building. . . .
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-310 (2003).Â  A â€œbuildingâ€ is a â€œ[s]tructure designed for habitation, shelter, storage . . . and the like.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 194 (6th ed. 1990).Â  
Because we find no South Carolina case directly on point, we look to general rules of statutory construction.Â  Criminal statutes must be strictly construed against the State.Â  State v. Myers, 313 S.C. 391, 393, 438 S.E.2d 236, 237 (1993).Â  However, words in a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning.Â  Id.Â  Our courts take a common sense approach in defining the terms associated with the burglary statutes.Â  See id. (â€œ[B]y including â€˜buildingâ€™ the definition of â€˜dwelling houseâ€™ is broad enough to include a boat in which a person lodges.â€).Â  See also State v. Stone, 350 S.C. 442, 446, 567 S.E.2d 244, 246 (2002) (finding a screened porch meets the statutory definition of a dwelling).Â  Applying a common sense meaning to the words used to define a â€œbuildingâ€ for purposes of the burglary statute leads to the inescapable conclusion that the crawl space is a part of the main building and therefore fits within the statutory definition of a building.Â  
We find support from other jurisdictions that have found similar spaces constitute a building.Â  See Garrett v. State, 578 S.E.2d 460, 463 (Ga. Ct. App. 2002) (finding a shelter with a contiguous wall used for storage for the main building is part of the main building); State v. Brower, 104 N.W. 284, 285 (Iowa 1905) (holding the word â€œbuilding,â€ within its accepted and legal signification, includes the cellar or basement); State v. Couch, 720 P.2d 1387, 1389-90 (Wash. Ct. App. 1986) (upholding conviction of second-degree burglary of building; finding basement of building part of the building as it was enclosed, associated with the building, and used in connection with the buildingâ€”statute, however, provided broader definition of building).Â  See generally Ghent, Jeffrey F., Annotation, What is â€œBuildingâ€ or â€œHouseâ€ Within Burglary or Breaking and Entering Statute, 68 A.L.R. 4th 425 (1989 & Supp. 2004).
In this case, the crawl space was underneath the office building and enclosed but for an opening concealed with a metal cover.Â  Under the facts of this case, we find the crawl space to be an integral part of the structure of the building and the trial court did not err in denying Middletonâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the conviction isÂ  
AFFIRMED. 
 KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Lee is a beer distributor.

title: Love v. Love
description: In this domestic matter, Wife appeals the termination of her alimony.  The court affirms, holding the parties' separation agreement granted the family court the authority to modify alimony, even to the point of termination.
text:
Love v. Love, 13898



  
    
      
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
Miller L. Love, Jr., Respondent,
v.
Ann B. Love, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Lisa A. Kinon, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4077
Heard December 7, 2005 â€“ Filed January 23, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Evander G. Jeffords, of Florence, and John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. MichaelÂ  Taylor, of Columbia, and Joseph O. Burroughs, Jr., of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Ann B. Love (Wife) appeals a family court order terminating her former husbandâ€™s alimony obligation.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Miller L. Love, Jr., (Husband) and Wife married in Florence, South Carolina, on June 3, 1962.Â  In January 1990, Wife was granted a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  The final divorce order incorporated a separation agreement entered into voluntarily by the parties.Â  The agreement addressed all of the major issues arising from the marriage, including, but not limited to, custody, visitation, spousal support, and the division of marital property.Â  
The parties agreed Husband would pay Wife $1,100 per month in alimony, an obligation which â€œshall end . . . upon the Wifeâ€™s remarriage or death, whichever occurs first.â€Â  With the exception of the provisions concerning the division of marital property, the agreement provides:

The provisions of this Agreement . . . shall be subject to the approval, confirmation and adoption of the Court, such that it becomes the Order of the Court and enforceable and modifiable as such.

In 1995, Wife petitioned the family court for a modification of the alimony agreement.Â  Prior to a hearing on the matter, the parties agreed Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation would increase by $600 per month, making the total monthly payment $1,700.
In 1995, Wife began dating Otis Goodwin, who had recently divorced his first wife.Â  Approximately a year and a half later, Wife moved in with Goodwin into the home they share today.Â  Goodwin testified that Wife pays him $200 per week for rent and her share of the utilities.Â  Over the course of their relationship, Goodwin loaned Wife $8,000, which was repaid, and a partially outstanding business loan of $25,000.Â  Wife is also a cardholder on Goodwinâ€™s American Express Account, although each pays his or her own portion of the credit card bill.Â  Mr. Goodwin has authority to write checks on Wifeâ€™s businessâ€™s checking account.Â  In 1997, Goodwin transferred to Wife a parcel of land in Surfside, South Carolina worth approximately $40,000 for the consideration of â€œ$5.00 love and affection.â€Â  Goodwin routinely attends holiday celebrations and special occasions with Wifeâ€™s family and Wifeâ€™s grandchildren refer to him with terms of affection such as â€œGrandpa O.â€Â  Although both Wife and Goodwin openly admit the romantic nature of their relationship, they are not formally married, nor do they express plans of marrying in the future.
In 2003, Husband filed the present action, petitioning the court for further modification of the alimony agreement.Â  Specifically, Husband alleged Wifeâ€™s amorous relationship and seven-year cohabitation with Goodwin constituted grounds for termination, or at least a substantial reduction, of his alimony obligation.Â  Husband averred that 2002 amendments to South Carolina Code Section 20-3-130(B)(1) (1976) prescribed this modification.Â  Alternatively, he argued Wifeâ€™s relationship was tantamount to marriage, warranting a termination of alimony as a significant change in circumstances under the common law of alimony.
The family court agreed with Husband and ordered the termination of alimony pursuant to both the recent statutory amendments and a determination that Wifeâ€™s relationship is â€œtantamount to marriage.â€Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We remain mindful that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
DISCUSSION
Wife argues the family court erred in terminating Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation because the family court lacked the authority to do so under both the law of this state and the terms of the agreement.Â  We disagree.
In Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 306 S.E.2d 624 (1983), our supreme court perspicuously held that the family court has the authority to modify alimony agreements â€œunless the agreement unambiguously denies the court jurisdictionâ€ to do so.Â  Id. at 352-53, 306 S.E.2d at 627; see also Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500-01, 602 S.E.2d 96, 98 (Ct. App. 2004); Stoddard v. Riddle, 362 S.C. 266, 268, 607 S.E.2d 97, 98 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Not only does the present agreement fail to expressly deny the family court this authority, it definitively grants the court such in stating that its terms â€œshall be subject to the approval, confirmation and adoption of the Court, such that it becomes the Order of the Court and enforceable and modifiable as such.â€Â  Accordingly, the family court had authority to modify the alimony in the present case.
Wife subtly concedes this point, a position due, no doubt, to the fact that she herself petitioned the court for an increase in alimony in 1995.Â  Wife, however, would have us somehow distinguish between the power to modify alimony and the power to terminate alimony.Â  We draw no such distinction.Â  Parties to a separation agreement may either agree to make alimony unmodifiable, or leave the issue within the traditional oversight of the family court.Â  See Moseley, 279 S.C. at 352-53, 306 S.E.2d at 627.Â  Should the parties agree to the latter, the family court may modify alimony to the same extent permissible in court-awarded alimony, a scope of authority which certainly includes the power to terminate payments based on substantial changes in the partiesâ€™ circumstances.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1976); Bryson v. Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œChanged conditions may warrant a modification or termination of alimony.â€).
Having concluded the family court possessed the authority to terminate alimony, we move to the issue of whether this authority was properly exercised in the present case.Â  As a ground for termination, the family court concluded Wifeâ€™s relationship with Goodwin was tantamount to marriage, constituting a substantial change in circumstances which warranted alimony termination.Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s termination of alimony on this ground.[1]
â€œThe purpose of alimony is to provide the ex-spouse a substitute for the support which was incident to the former marital relationship.â€Â  Croom v. Croom, 305 S.C. 158, 160, 406 S.E.2d 381, 382 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  â€œLiving with another, whether it is with a live-in lover, a relative, or a platonic housemate, changes [a personâ€™s] circumstances and alters [his or] her required financial support.â€Â  Vance v. Vance, 287 S.C. 615, 618, 340 S.E.2d 554, 555 (Ct. App. 1986).Â Â Â  Because the State has â€œa compelling interest in promoting marriage and discouraging meretricious relationships,â€ a rule allowing alimony to continue when the supported spouse cohabits without marrying is â€œillogical and offensive to public policy.â€Â  Croom, 305 S.C. at 160, 406 S.E.2d at 382.Â  Accordingly, courts will treat the relationship between a supported spouse and a third party as â€œtantamount to marriageâ€ and terminate alimony when the two cohabitate for an extended period of time and some degree of economic reliance between them is established.Â  See, e.g., Bryson, 347 S.C. at 225, 553 S.E.2d at 496; Vance, 287 S.C. at 617-18, 340 S.E.2d at 555.
Such a relationship is certainly established in the case at bar.Â  Wife and Goodwin have cohabitated for over seven years.Â  Despite their assertions to the contrary, the record reflects the pair share a substantial amount of expenses, be it in the form of loans, reduced rent, or gifts.Â  The record also reflects the romantic nature of the partyâ€™s relationship and the unmistakable connection between Goodwin and Wifeâ€™s family.Â  See Bryson, 347 S.C. at 226, 553 S.E.2d at 496 (considering the bonds between cohabitating partner and the alimony recipientâ€™s family in determining whether relationship was tantamount to marriage).Â  We therefore affirm the family courtâ€™s conclusion that Wife and Goodwin are in relationship that is tantamount to marriage.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order terminating Wifeâ€™s alimony is hereby
 AFFIRMED.[2]
 STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Because we affirm the family court on the ground Wifeâ€™s relationship constitutes a change of circumstance warranting alimony termination, we need not address the statutory grounds for the family courtâ€™s termination of alimony.Â  SeeÂ  Iâ€™On , L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000) (holding an appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the record on appeal).
[2] Because we affirm the result reached by the family court, we likewise affirm the family courtâ€™s determination that neither party is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  As Wife is clearly not the prevailing party in this action, the family court properly denied her request for fees.Â  See E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992) (holding that the result obtained in litigation is an important factor in the consideration of whether to grant a party attorneyâ€™s fees).

description: In this medical malpractice action, Terry Lee Stokes, representative of Jennings E. Stokes's estate, appeals from a jury verdict in favor of Spartanburg Regional Medical Center.  Appellant argues the trial judge erred in failing to instruct the jury that it could draw a negative inference from the Hospital's faillure to preserve critical pieces of medical evidence. text:
Stokes v. Spartanburg Regional



  
    
      
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
Terry Stokes, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Jennings E. Stokes,
Appellant,
v.
Spartanburg Regional Medical Center; and Robert A. Cochran, Jr., M.D., and David C. Hull, M.D., each individually and as Agents/Employees of Hull, Green, Woods, Cochran and
Woollen; and Hull, Green, Woods, Cochran and Woollen; and John Graham, CRNA, Defendants,
of whom Spartanburg Regional Medical Center is
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4078
Heard November 10, 2005 â€“ Filed January 23, 2006Â Â 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Kristi F. Curtis, David W. Goldman, Diane M. Rodriguez, all of Sumter, for Appellant.
Perry Boulier and Ginger D. Goforth, both of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: In this medical malpractice action, Terry Lee Stokes, the personal representative of Jennings E. Stokesâ€™s estate, appeals from a jury verdict in favor of Spartanburg Regional Medical Center (the Hospital).Â  Appellant argues the trial judge erred in failing to instruct the jury that it could draw a negative inference from the Hospitalâ€™s failure to preserve critical pieces of medical evidence.Â  We reverse and remand. 
FACTS
On June 10, 1998, Jennings Stokes, age seventy-seven, underwent surgery to remove his thyroid and lymph nodes, which were cancerous.Â  Dr. Hull performed the surgery at the Hospital.Â  No complications arose during the surgery, and according to Dr. Hull, Stokesâ€™s prognosis was very good.Â  
After surgery, Stokes was transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit (recovery room), where he remained for two hours.Â  While there, he received oxygen through a mask, and nurses monitored his oxygen saturation levels with a device called a pulse oximeter. During this two-hour stay in the recovery room, Stokes received five doses of morphine for pain, and nurses called Dr. Hull two times because of bloody drainage coming from the neck incision.Â  
From the recovery room, Stokes was transferred to the third floor of the Hospital, which is designated â€œpediatrics.â€[1]Â  While on the third floor, Stokes no longer had an oxygen mask and was not being monitored with a pulse oximeter.Â  Stokes arrived on the third floor at 6:45 p.m., and according to the nurseâ€™s notes, by 7:30 p.m., his neck was â€œswollenâ€ and his wound dressing was â€œsaturated.â€ Thirty minutes later, Stokes complained of pain and received Demerol combined with Phenergan, a narcotic medication. According to the nurse, Stokes began having â€œdifficulty breathingâ€ at 8:30 p.m., and at 8:55 p.m., his breathing stopped.Â  Five minutes later, a â€œcodeâ€ was initiated. 
During the code, a nurse anesthetist tried to intubate Stokes in order to provide him with oxygen, but the intubation was unsuccessful.Â  The nurse anesthetist called the anesthesiologist for help.Â  Dr. Cochran, a partner of Dr. Hullâ€™s, was also notified of the code, and took charge of the resuscitation.Â  At 9:21 p.m., Dr. Long, the anesthesiologist, arrived and successfully intubated Stokes.Â  Despite the intubation, Stokes could not be revived.Â  Dr. Cochran signed the death certificate, stating the cause of death was â€œrespiratory failure.â€Â  
Stokesâ€™s daughter-in-law, Ann, is a registered nurse and has worked in the Hospitalâ€™s recovery room for fifteen years.Â  Ann was by Stokesâ€™s side while he was in the recovery room, and she stayed with him even when he was transferred to the third floor.Â  While Ann was there, other nurses were charged with caring for Stokes, but Ann monitored him as well. 
After Stokes died, his son, Terry, served as the personal representative of Stokesâ€™s estate, and it was in this capacity that Terry (hereinafter Appellant) brought a survivorship action and wrongful death action against the Hospital and other defendants who are not parties to this appeal.Â  At trial, Appellant and the Hospital disputed the cause of Stokesâ€™s death.Â  
Appellant argued that Stokes died from a lack of oxygen, which could have been prevented if the Hospitalâ€™s staff had not deviated from the standard of care for a patient recovering from a thyroidectomy.Â  According to Appellantâ€™s experts, a well-known complication of this type of surgery is airway obstruction caused by the swelling of soft tissue in the patientâ€™s neck or postoperative bleeding, which can collect in one area and form a hematoma. A hematoma is especially dangerous after surgery to the neck because it can clog a patientâ€™s windpipe. To decrease the chance of a patientâ€™s airway being obstructed, Appellantâ€™s experts testified the patient should be on supplemental oxygen and vigilantly monitored for signs of respiratory distress.Â  The experts further opined that a tracheotomy procedure kit should be kept next to the patientâ€™s bed in the event the patientâ€™s airway becomes so obstructed that an intubation tube cannot be placed into the patientâ€™s throat and a â€œsurgical airwayâ€ must be created.Â  It was the Appellantâ€™s position that the Hospital deviated from the standard of care by transferring Stokes to the third floor, where the nurse in charge had never cared for a thyroidectomy patient before and was not instructed to continue administering oxygen to Stokes.Â  The Appellant further argued Stokesâ€™s third floor placement was unacceptable because there was no tracheotomy kit at his bedside.Â  
The Hospital argued that Stokes died from a sudden and unexpected event, most probably a heart attack.Â  It relied heavily on Ann, who testified as both an eyewitness and an expert witness.Â  According to Ann, Stokes showed no signs of respiratory distress, though his respirations did slow down after he received pain medication.Â  Ann found this reaction normal, but out of an abundance of caution, she stepped outside the room and asked for a pulse oximeter to measure his oxygen saturation level. She testified she left the room for less than a minute, and when she returned, she found Stokesâ€™s condition had deteriorated rapidly.Â  His breathing was shallow, his pulse weak, and he was unresponsive.Â  The Hospital also presented evidence that Stokes had suffered a minor heart attack sometime prior to the surgery.Â  
During trial, Appellant pointed out two pieces of medical documentation that were missing from Stokesâ€™s medical records.Â  First, there was evidence that blood had been drawn from Stokesâ€™s artery during the code.Â  This blood sample was drawn so that an arterial blood gas could be performed, which would indicate whether oxygen was reaching Stokesâ€™s bloodstream. The medical records, however, did not contain the results from this test.Â  The second piece of missing evidence was the vital signs flow chart prepared by the floor nurse at the time of Stokesâ€™s death.Â  The Hospital was unsure why the chart was missing, but speculated that it was misplaced during the code.Â  
At trial, the judge held a conference to discuss jury charges.Â  One of Plaintiffâ€™s requested charges was a â€œspoliation of evidenceâ€ charge, which allowed jurors to draw a negative inference if it found the Hospitalâ€™s explanation regarding the missing records unsatisfactory.Â  The trial judge agreed to the charge, and the Hospital did not object.Â  However, when it came time to charge the jury, the trial judge failed to give the â€œspoliation of evidenceâ€ instruction.Â  Appellant objected, but the court overruled the objection, explaining: â€œThat charge I have some problems with this.â€ 
When the jury came back with a defense verdict, Appellantâ€™s counsel moved for a new trial based on the jury charge.Â  The trial judge denied the motion, stating: â€œI could not have charged it as written I donâ€™t believe.Â  I would have had to have modified it.Â  And hopefully, my charge as a whole covered it and didnâ€™t prejudice your case in any way I hope.â€Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court is required to charge the current and correct law.Â  Burroughs v. Worsham, 352 S.C. 382, 392, 574 S.E.2d 215, 220 (Ct. App. 2002). When reviewing a jury charge for alleged error, our court must consider the charge as a whole, in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial. Id.Â  An erroneous jury charge will not result in a verdict being reversed unless the charge prejudiced the appellantâ€™s case.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant argues the trial court erred in failing to instruct the jury on â€œspoliation of evidence,â€ especially when the Hospital did not object to the proposed charge.[2]Â  We agree.
In Welch v. Gibbons, 211 S.C. 516, 46 S.E.2d 147 (1948), distinguished by Ex parte Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., 248 S.C. 412, 415-16, 150 S.E.2d 525, 526-27 (1966), our supreme court recognized circumstances under which a jury should be able to consider missing evidence.Â  In Welch, the plaintiff sued a bottling plant, alleging it sold a soft drink which contained poison.Â  The plaintiff had in his possession the bottled drink, but neither tested the contents himself nor allowed the defendant to test its contents.Â  The supreme court held â€œthe evidence excluded was a circumstance which the jury should have been permitted to consider.â€ Id. The court also noted, â€œit is open to the plaintiff to explain his refusal to allow a chemical analysis to be made of the contents of this bottle and on another trial he is at liberty to do so.â€
Relying on the holding in Welch, our supreme court later upheld a jury charge which advised that â€œwhen evidence is lost or destroyed by a party an inference may be drawn by the jury that the evidence which was lost or destroyed by that party would have been adverse to that party.â€Â  Kershaw County Bd. of Educ. v. U.S. Gypsum Co., 302 S.C. 390, 394, 396 S.E.2d 369, 372 (1990).Â  In Kershaw, the school board sued the manufacturer of the ceiling plaster that had been installed in many of Kershaw Countyâ€™s schools, alleging the plaster contained asbestos.Â  The trial court issued an order requiring the manufacturer be notified prior to any asbestos being removed.Â  Despite this order, the school board did not notify the manufacturer before asbestos abatement was conducted at one of its schools, so the manufacturer moved for judgment in its favor on the claims related to that school.Â  The trial court denied the motion, but charged the jury as described above.Â  In upholding the charge, the supreme court stated: â€œ[T]he trial courtâ€™s decision was proper under the facts of this case.â€Â  Id.  
In the case at hand, there was evidence that two pieces of medical evidence were missing from Stokesâ€™s record: results from a blood test and the floor nurseâ€™s chart detailing Stokesâ€™s vital signs on the evening of his death.Â  Rebutting that evidence, the Hospital suggested the blood drawn from Stokesâ€™s artery on the night of his death may never have been sent to the laboratory for testing.Â  As for the missing chart, the Hospital speculated it may have been lost during the code.[3]Â  While the jury may well have accepted the Hospitalâ€™s explanations, it was also in its province to draw a negative inference from the Hospitalâ€™s failure to produce those pieces of evidence.Â  See id.
Appellant requested the trial court charge the jury as follows:

I charge you that when a party fails to preserve material evidence for trial, it is for you to determine whether the party has offered a satisfactory explanation for that failure.Â  If you find the explanation unsatisfactory, you are permitted â€“ but not required â€“ to draw the inference that the evidence would have been unfavorable to the partyâ€™s claim.

We believe this language reflects the law of South Carolina and should have been charged based on the evidence presented in this case.Â  While we recognize that no exact language is required, the charge as given made no mention of missing evidence at all.Â  Thus, we cannot say, as the Hospital urges, that the substance of the request was included in the trial judgeâ€™s general instructions.
In addition to being erroneous, we find the failure to charge on â€œspoliation of evidenceâ€ was prejudicial to Appellant.Â  Appellantâ€™s malpractice claim against the Hospital hinged on the jury believing Stokes died from lack of oxygen rather than from a sudden and unexpected heart attack.Â  Both pieces of evidence the Appellant alleges are missing would have helped determine how Stokes died.Â  Thus, it was crucial to Appellantâ€™s case that the jury know it could draw a negative inference from the Hospitalâ€™s failure to produce those important pieces of evidence.Â  We therefore find the Appellant was prejudiced by the trial courtâ€™s failure to instruct the jury on â€œspoliation of evidence.â€ See, e.g., Baker v. Weaver, 279 S.C. 479, 309 S.E.2d 770 (Ct. App. 1983) (finding trial courtâ€™s erroneous jury charge prejudicial where requested instruction involved a substantial feature of the case).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find that the trial court erred in failing to charge the jury on â€œspoliation of evidenceâ€ and that this error was prejudicial.Â  Accordingly, we reverse and remand for a new trial.
REVERSED and REMANDED.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] The third floor is also an â€œoverflow areaâ€ for patients receiving urological or gynecological surgery. 
[2] The Hospital initially argues this issue is not preserved for review because the term â€œspoliation of evidenceâ€ was never referenced at trial.Â  While the exact term was not used, Appellant undeniably requested the jury be instructed that it could, but was not required to, draw a negative inference when a party fails to preserve material evidence for trial. Thus, we find the Hospitalâ€™s lack of preservation argument to be manifestly without merit.Â  See Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR (â€œThe court of appeals need not address a point that is manifestly without merit.â€).
[3] In its brief, the Hospital also argues there was no evidence the vital signs flow chart maintained by the floor nurse was missing because the nurse did not testify at trial.Â  However, several other witnesses testified that they reviewed the nurseâ€™s deposition and that she filled out the chart during her treatment of Stokes.Â  This testimony came in without objection, and therefore the jury was presented with evidence that the chart was missing.

title: State v. Bailey
description: The State appeals the circuit court's decision to overturn Bailey's magistrate court conviction for disorderly conduct.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Roy Bailey, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4079
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 23, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Robert Bethune King, Jr., of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  The State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision to overturn Roy Baileyâ€™s magistrate court conviction for disorderly conduct.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
On October 15, 2002, Roy Bailey and Calvin Ladd, one of Baileyâ€™s employees, pulled into the Speedway gas station to get gas for the company truck.Â  The company had a gas card with Speedway, and Ladd got out of the truck, swiped the gas card on the pump, and pumped $29 worth of gas.Â  After pumping the gas, Ladd informed Bailey that the pump did not print a receipt.Â  The two went inside the gas station to request a receipt from the clerk.Â  The clerk informed the two that the gas had not been paid for.Â  A dispute arose over whether the transaction on the gas card actually processed, and the police were called.Â  
Deputy Stacy Brooks arrived on the scene.Â  He testified that when he entered the store, Bailey was â€œextremely argumentative and loud and boisterousâ€ such that customers inside the store were stopping to stare.Â  Brooks stated he attempted to calm Bailey and asked him to step outside the store.Â  Deputy Giles Gladsen arrived at that point and remained outside with Bailey while Brooks returned inside the store to get the clerkâ€™s version of the events.Â  After the clerk showed Brooks the computer screen indicating that Bailey did not pay for the gas, Brooks returned outside to inform Bailey that he needed to pay for the gas.Â  Brooks testified that Bailey then became loud, boisterous, and argumentative with him and Gladsen.Â  According to Brooks, although Bailey never used profanity, his behavior drew a lot of attention from people inside and outside the store and that Bailey was â€œabsolutely disorderly within the view of the general public.â€Â  Brooks also testified that after Bailey refused to pay for the gas, he â€œcontinued being loud and boisterous with myself and Deputy Gladsen.Â  At which point we had no choice but to place him under arrest for at the time petit larceny and public disorderly conduct.â€[2]Â  Deputy Gladsen similarly testified that Bailey was very loud and became disorderly and belligerent with him outside the store within close proximity of other people.Â  Bailey was arrested for disorderly conduct.Â  He complained of chest pains, and he was taken to the hospital for treatment.Â Â Â  
The State rested its case after presenting the testimony of Deputies Brooks and Gladsen.Â  Bailey immediately moved for a directed verdict, arguing the State failed to prove that Bailey used fighting words towards the police officers, and thus, he could not be convicted of disorderly conduct pursuant to State v. Perkins, 306 S.C. 353, 412 S.E.2d 385 (1991).Â  The magistrate agreed Perkins may have some applicability, but he found there was evidence that Bailey was loud and boisterous in violation of section 16-17-530 such that the matter should go to the jury.Â  After the denial of the motion for a directed verdict, Bailey presented evidence.[3]Â Â Â  
Calvin Ladd, the employee with Bailey, testified that he and Bailey went inside the store to get a receipt for the gas card transaction.Â  According to Ladd, he did â€œall the talkingâ€ with the store clerk regarding the gas card transaction, not Bailey, and the discussion was calm.Â  Ladd stated Bailey was not loud with the deputies when they were talking outside, and he could not hear what was being said.Â  
Bailey similarly testified at trial that Ladd was the person who spoke with the store clerk regarding the gas card.Â  Bailey testified that once he was outside the store, Deputy Brooks threatened him, stating that Bailey should pay for the gas or else Brooks would find something with which to charge him.Â  Bailey denied ever being loud or disrespectful with the deputies, and he stated that he only yelled when he was having chest pains and wanted medical attention.Â  Bailey also denied there was a large crowd at the gas station watching the events.Â  Bailey was convicted by the jury and sentenced to thirty days in jail, suspended upon the payment of a $258 fine.Â Â  
Bailey appealed his conviction to the circuit court, arguing the magistrate court erred in:Â  (1) failing to grant his motion for a directed verdict; and (2) failing to give his requested jury instructions, especially the one regarding â€œfighting wordsâ€ which must be present in order to charge one with disorderly conduct towards a police officer pursuant to Perkins.Â  After hearing arguments by both parties, the circuit court issued a form order reversing Baileyâ€™s conviction.Â  The State appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Appeals from magistrate court convictions are made to the circuit court.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§18-3-10 (Supp. 2004).Â  The circuit court, acting as the appellate court, reviews the matters raised in the notice of appeal.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-70 (Supp. 2004) (â€œThe appeal must be heard by the Court of Common Pleas upon the grounds of exceptions made and upon the papers required under this chapter, without the examination of witnesses . . . .â€); State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 457, 556 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œIn criminal appeals from magistrate or municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de novo review, but instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate exception.â€).Â  The appellate court reviewing the circuit court appeal may review for errors of law only.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues the circuit court erred in reversing Baileyâ€™s conviction because: (1) the directed verdict issue was not preserved; (2) it was error to rely on Perkins; and (3) there was sufficient evidence to support Baileyâ€™s conviction.Â  We disagree.Â  
A. Preservation
The State initially argues the circuit court erred in reversing the magistrate courtâ€™s denial of Baileyâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on an unpreserved ground because Bailey failed to renew his motion for a directed verdict after the presentation of all the evidence.[4]Â  
The State raises this issue for the first time on appeal to this court.Â  The State never brought the preservation issue, an additional sustaining ground, to the attention of the circuit court on appeal.Â  See Iâ€™on, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (noting that although a respondent may raise an additional sustaining ground on appeal, respondent may also â€œabandon an additional sustaining ground . . . by failing to raise it in the appellate brief.â€).Â  Instead, both Bailey and the State vigorously argued the merits of whether Bailey was entitled to a directed verdict based upon Perkins.Â  The circuit court reviewed the issues raised before it and reversed Baileyâ€™s conviction.Â  
Because the preservation issue was never brought to the attention of the circuit court on appeal, no ruling on the matter was ever issued.Â  Further, nothing in the record indicates the State brought the matter to the attention of the circuit court in a petition for rehearing.Â  Accordingly, it is not appropriate for this court to review it.Â  See City of Columbia v. Ervin, 330 S.C. 516, 519-20, 500 S.E.2d 483, 485 (1998) (noting that the Court of Appeals should not have addressed an issue on appeal where Ervin failed to raise the issue to the circuit court as intermediate appellate court); Condor, Inc., v. Board of Zoning Appeals, 328 S.C. 173, 178 n.4, 493 S.E.2d 342, 344 n.4 (1997) (holding that an issue which was not presented in the verified petition of appeal to the circuit court was not properly preserved for review by the supreme court); see also Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 75-76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (noting in dicta that petitioner had preservation problems of its own where petitioner complained that issues reviewed by the Court of Appeals were not preserved for appellate review, but petitioner failed to â€œraise all of these issues to the Court of Appeals in its petition for rehearing;â€ the court further noted that it believed the issues were preserved for review by the Court of Appeals).Â  
B.Â  Propriety of Directed Verdict
The State argues the circuit court erred in reversing the denial of Baileyâ€™s motion for a directed verdict because it erroneously relied upon Perkins and because enough evidence existed to support Baileyâ€™s guilt.Â  We disagree.
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 583, 541 S.E.2d 254, 256 (2001); State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999); State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 62, 502 S.E.2d 63, 69 (1998).Â  When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence of evidence, not its weight.Â  Burdette, 335 S.C. at 46, 515 S.E.2d at 531; State v. Wakefield, 323 S.C. 189, 197, 473 S.E.2d 831, 835 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œIf there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.â€Â  Lollis, 343 S.C. at 584, 541 S.E.2d at 256.Â  â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.â€Â  State v. Rosemond, 356 S.C. 426, 429, 589 S.E.2d 757, 758 (2003). 
Bailey was charged with public disorderly conduct.Â  The pertinent portion of the public disorderly conduct statute provides that it is a misdemeanor for a person to â€œbe found . . . at any public place or public gathering . . . otherwise conducting himself in a disorderly or boisterous manner . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-530(a) (2003).Â  However, there is an additional requirement that â€œfighting wordsâ€ must be used when one is charged with disorderly conduct towards a police officer.Â  See State v. Perkins, 306 S.C. 353, 355, 412 S.E.2d 385, 386 (1991) (â€œ[A]ppellants cannot be punished under Â§ 16-17-530(a) for voicing their objections to sheriffâ€™s officers where the record indicates no use of fighting words.â€); see also City of Landrum v. Sarratt, 352 S.C. 139, 144, 572 S.E.2d 476, 479 (Ct. App. 2002) (noting the Perkins court narrowly applied the fighting words exception to â€œcases involving words addressed to a police officerâ€); State v. LaCoste, 347 S.C. 153, 163-64, 553 S.E.2d 464, 470 (Ct. App. 2001) (finding there was ample evidence of disorderly conduct to support the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion for a directed verdict where the defendant shouted obscenities at officers, threw his hands up in a hostile manner, refused to comply with officersâ€™ demands, challenged the officers, and taunted the officers about their inability to get him under control); City of Columbia v. Brown, 316 S.C. 432, 436-37, 450 S.E.2d 117, 119-20 (Ct. App. 1994) (noting that the defendantâ€™s actions met the definition of â€œfighting wordsâ€ where he shouted obscenities and racial slurs at police officers on a public street, he was not challenging any police action, and he was repeatedly told by the officers to leave the area prior to arresting him for loitering).Â  
In Perkins, the two appellants went to the sheriffâ€™s office to obtain a copy of an incident report in order to obtain a warrant from the magistrate.Â  After being told that the incident report was not yet available, the appellants became upset and raised their voices inside the sheriffâ€™s office.Â  They were arrested upon leaving the sheriffâ€™s office and were charged with disorderly conduct.Â  In reversing the appellantsâ€™ convictions, our state supreme court noted as follows:

â€œ[T]he First Amendment protects a significant amount of verbal criticism and challenge directed at police officers.â€Â  City of Houston v. Hill, 482 U.S. 451, 461, 107 S.Ct. 2502, 2505, 96 L.Ed.2d 398, 412 (1987).Â  The State may not punish a person for voicing an objection to a police officer where no â€œfighting wordsâ€ are used.Â  Norwell v. Cincinnati, 414 U.S. 14, 94 S.Ct. 187, 38 L.Ed.2d 170 (1973).Â  To punish only spoken words addressed to a police officer, a statute must be limited in scope to fighting words that â€œby their very utterance inflict injury or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace.â€Â  Hill, 482 U.S. at 461-62, 107 S.Ct. at 2509-10, 96 L.Ed.2d at 412 (quoting Lewis v. City of New Orleans, 415 U.S. 130, 94 S.Ct. 970, 39 L.Ed.2d 214 (1974)).Â  As further noted by the United States Supreme Court, the â€œfighting wordsâ€ exception may require narrow application in cases involving words addressed to a police officer â€œbecause a properly trained officer may reasonably be expected to exercise a higher degree of restraint than the average citizen.â€Â  Hill, 482 U.S. at 462, 107 S.Ct. at 2510, 96 L.Ed.2d at 412.Â  As stated by the high court:Â  The freedom of individuals verbally to oppose or challenge police action without thereby risking arrest is one of the principal characteristics by which we distinguish a free nation from a police state.Â  Id. at 462-63, 107 S.Ct. at 2510, 96 L.Ed.2d at 412-13.Â  

Perkins, 306 S.C. at 386, 412 S.E.2d at 354-55.
In the present case, the circuit court relied upon Perkins in reversing Baileyâ€™s conviction.Â  The courtâ€™s form order stated â€œOfficerâ€™s [sic] clearly arrested Mr. Bailey for being boisterous toward the officers.Â  Under Perkins, the case is reversed as a matter of law.â€Â  Thus, it appears the circuit court ruled Bailey was entitled to a directed verdict pursuant to Perkins.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, there was evidence to support a finding that Baileyâ€™s conduct inside the store amounted to â€œdisorderly conductâ€ such that a directed verdict would be improper.Â  However, Bailey was not arrested for his conduct inside the store.Â  Despite the deputiesâ€™ testimony that Bailey was disorderly in view of the public, Bailey was not placed under arrest until after his confrontation with the deputies outside.Â  There is no evidence in the record that anything Bailey said to the deputies amounted to â€œfighting words.â€Â  Thus, pursuant to Perkins, Baileyâ€™s actions outside did not amount to disorderly conduct.Â  Bailey was entitled to a directed verdict on the disorderly conduct charge.Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court did not commit an error of law in reversing Baileyâ€™s conviction.Â  
CONCLUSION
Because Bailey was arrested for being boisterous with the deputies and there was no evidence that his language amounted to â€œfighting words,â€ the circuit court correctly reversed Baileyâ€™s conviction for disorderly conduct.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Although the deputies intended to charge Bailey with petit larceny for failing to pay for the gas, Baileyâ€™s employee paid for the gas, and the charges were dropped.Â Â Â Â  
[3] Bailey failed to renew his motion for directed verdict at the close of all evidence.Â Â  
[4]Â  If a defendant presents evidence after the denial of his directed verdict motion at the close of the Stateâ€™s case, he must make another directed verdict motion at the close of all evidence in order to appeal the sufficiency of the evidence.Â  State v. Adams, 332 S.C. 139, 144, 504 S.E.2d 124, 126-27 (Ct. App. 1998).
